name: Abecma
description: Abecma (idecabtagene vicleucel) is an autologous, one-time CAR T-cell therapy that reprograms a patients own T cells to target and eliminate relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma cells in adults.
mechanism_of_action: The T cells are engineered in a laboratory to express a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR), which specifically recognizes B-cell maturation antigen (BCMA), a protein found on multiple myeloma cells. Once infused back into the patient, these modified T cells seek out and bind to BCMA-expressing myeloma cells. Upon binding, the CAR T cells become activated, triggering an immune response that leads to the destruction of multiple myeloma cells through cytotoxic mechanisms.

name: Abilify
description: Abilify (aripiprazole) is an atypical antipsychotic that modulates dopamine and serotonin activity, used to treat schizophrenia (≥13 years), bipolar I disorder (≥10 years), major depressive disorder (adjunct in adults), Tourette’s disorder (≥6 years), and irritability associated with autistic disorder (≥6 years).
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a partial agonist at dopamine D2 receptors and serotonin 5-HT1a receptors, stabilizing dopamine activity in mesolimbic and mesocortical pathways. Functions as an antagonist at serotonin 5-HT₂ₐ receptors, modulating serotonin signaling to improve mood and cognitive symptoms. This dual activity balances excessive dopamine in psychosis-prone brain regions while enhancing dopamine signaling in areas linked to motivation and cognition, earning it the label: dopamine system stabilizer.

name: Abiraterone
description: Abiraterone is used in combination with other steroids to treat metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) and metastatic high-risk castration-sensitive prostate cancer, both of which are advanced forms of prostate cancer that have spread beyond the prostate gland and are resistant or sensitive to hormonal therapies that lower testosterone. Abiraterone works by reducing androgen production in the body.
mechanism_of_action: Abiraterone is an androgen biosynthesis inhibitor that selectively and irreversibly inhibits the enzyme CYP17A1 (17α-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase), a key enzyme in androgen production in the testes, adrenal glands, and prostate tumor tissue; this inhibition blocks the synthesis of androgens (including testosterone and dihydrotestosterone), thereby depriving prostate cancer cells of the hormones that drive their growth and survival.

name: Acetaminophen
description: Acetaminophen (also known as paracetamol) is widely used to relieve mild to moderate pain (such as headache, backache, toothache, muscular aches, minor arthritis pain, and menstrual cramps) and to reduce fever.
mechanism_of_action: Acetaminophen acts primarily in the central nervous system, where it inhibits the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway-mainly by noncompetitively blocking the peroxidase site of COX enzymes-thereby reducing the synthesis of prostaglandins involved in pain and fever signaling. Unlike NSAIDs, acetaminophen has minimal effect on peripheral COX enzymes and thus lacks significant anti-inflammatory activity. Additionally, its analgesic effect may be enhanced by its metabolite AM404, which activates cannabinoid (CB1) and TRPV1 receptors in the brain and spinal cord, further modulating pain transmission.

name: Acetazolamide
description: Acetazolamide is used to treat glaucoma (to lower intraocular pressure), idiopathic intracranial hypertension, certain types of epilepsy, edema (fluid retention) due to heart failure or medications, and to prevent or reduce symptoms of altitude (mountain) sickness.
mechanism_of_action: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that blocks the enzyme carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule of the kidney and other tissues, leading to decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate, sodium, and chloride, resulting in increased urinary excretion of these ions and water; this causes urine alkalinization, systemic metabolic acidosis, and reductions in intraocular pressure, intracranial pressure, and edema. In the central nervous system, acetazolamide’s inhibition of carbonic anhydrase alters neuronal excitability by acidifying the internal milieu, modulating GABAergic signaling and ion channel activity, which contributes to its anticonvulsant effects.

name: Acetylcysteine
description: Acetylcysteine (N-acetylcysteine, NAC) is primarily used as an antidote for acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose to prevent or reduce liver damage, and as a mucolytic agent to loosen thick mucus in respiratory conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), cystic fibrosis, pneumonia, and bronchitis. It is also used off-label for a variety of other indications, including prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy, acute hepatic failure, and certain psychiatric and neurological conditions
mechanism_of_action: Acetylcysteine acts as a precursor to glutathione, replenishing depleted glutathione stores in the liver during acetaminophen overdose, which enables detoxification of the toxic metabolite NAPQI and prevents cellular injury. As a mucolytic, acetylcysteine’s free sulfhydryl groups break disulfide bonds in mucoproteins, reducing mucus viscosity and facilitating its clearance from the airways. Additionally, acetylcysteine has antioxidant properties, directly scavenging free radicals and modulating intracellular redox states, which may contribute to its protective effects in various tissues.

name: Actemra
description: Actemra is indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis in adults, giant cell arteritis, systemic sclerosis-associated interstitial lung disease (SSc-ILD), polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (PJIA), systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA) in children aged 2 years and older, severe or life-threatening cytokine release syndrome (CRS) associated with CAR T-cell therapy, and for hospitalized adults with COVID-19 who require supplemental oxygen or mechanical ventilation.
mechanism_of_action: Actemra is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody that binds to both soluble and membrane-bound interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptors (sIL-6R and mIL-6R), thereby inhibiting IL-6-mediated signaling; this blockade reduces the pro-inflammatory and immune-activating effects of IL-6, a cytokine central to the pathogenesis of autoimmune and inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and giant cell arteritis.

name: Actos
description: Actos (pioglitazone) is prescribed to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus, typically as an adjunct to diet and exercise, and may be used alone or in combination with other antidiabetic medications; it is not indicated for type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis.
mechanism_of_action: Actos is a thiazolidinedione that acts as a potent and selective agonist for peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ), a nuclear receptor predominantly expressed in adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and liver; activation of PPARγ modulates transcription of insulin-responsive genes, leading to increased insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues, enhanced glucose uptake by muscle and fat cells, decreased hepatic glucose production, and improved glycemic control without stimulating insulin secretion.

name: Acyclovir
description: Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat infections caused by herpes viruses, including herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2 (causing genital herpes and cold sores), varicella-zoster virus (causing chickenpox and shingles), and is also used to prevent and treat herpes infections in immunocompromised patients.
mechanism_of_action: Acyclovir is a synthetic nucleoside analogue that, after being selectively phosphorylated by viral thymidine kinase to acyclovir monophosphate and further converted by host cell enzymes to acyclovir triphosphate, inhibits viral DNA synthesis by competitively inhibiting viral DNA polymerase, incorporating into viral DNA to cause chain termination, and inactivating the viral DNA polymerase enzyme.

name: Adderall
description: Adderall is prescribed for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children and adults, as well as narcolepsy, a sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness.
mechanism_of_action: Adderall is a central nervous system stimulant composed of mixed amphetamine salts (dextroamphetamine and levoamphetamine) that increases the synaptic concentrations of dopamine and norepinephrine by promoting their release from presynaptic neurons and inhibiting their reuptake; this is achieved through actions on monoamine transporters (DAT, NET), vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2), and trace amine-associated receptor 1 (TAAR1), ultimately enhancing neurotransmission in brain regions responsible for attention, alertness, and impulse control.

name: Advair Diskus
description: Advair Diskus is a combination inhaler prescribed for the maintenance treatment of asthma in adults and children aged 4 years and older, and for the long-term management of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema, to improve breathing and reduce the frequency of exacerbations; it is not intended for the relief of acute bronchospasm or as a rescue inhaler.
mechanism_of_action: Advair Diskus combines fluticasone propionate, an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) that acts as a potent glucocorticoid receptor agonist to suppress airway inflammation, and salmeterol, a long-acting beta2-adrenergic agonist (LABA) that stimulates beta2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, leading to prolonged bronchodilation; together, these actions reduce airway swelling and relax airway muscles, improving airflow and controlling chronic respiratory symptoms.

name: Advil
description: Advil (ibuprofen) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve mild to moderate pain from conditions such as headaches, muscle aches, backaches, menstrual cramps, dental pain, minor arthritis, and to reduce fever and inflammation.
mechanism_of_action: Ibuprofen is a non-selective inhibitor of cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) enzymes, blocking the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins and thromboxanes, thereby reducing the synthesis of mediators responsible for pain, inflammation, and fever.

name: Afinitor
description: Afinitor (everolimus) is used to treat several types of advanced cancers and tumors, including hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer (in combination with exemestane), advanced renal cell carcinoma (kidney cancer), progressive neuroendocrine tumors of pancreatic, gastrointestinal, or lung origin, and certain brain tumors (subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, SEGA) and kidney tumors (renal angiomyolipoma) associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). It is also indicated as adjunctive therapy for partial-onset seizures in TSC patients.
mechanism_of_action: Afinitor is an mTOR inhibitor: it binds to the protein FKBP-12 to form a complex that inhibits the activity of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), a kinase involved in cell growth, proliferation, metabolism, and angiogenesis. By blocking mTOR, Afinitor reduces cancer cell proliferation, glucose uptake, and the formation of new blood vessels (angiogenesis), thereby slowing tumor growth and spread.

name: Agamree
description: Agamree (vamorolone) is indicated for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) in patients aged 2 years and older, a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and degeneration.
mechanism_of_action: Agamree is a first-in-class dissociative corticosteroid that binds to both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid receptors, exerting anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects primarily through inhibition of nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) proinflammatory pathways, while exhibiting reduced activation of genes responsible for typical corticosteroid side effects and acting as a potent mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist; this unique profile aims to retain muscle-protective benefits and minimize adverse effects commonly seen with traditional corticosteroids.

name: Aimovig
description: Aimovig (erenumab-aooe) is a prescription medication used for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults, helping to reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.
mechanism_of_action: Aimovig is a fully human monoclonal antibody that selectively binds to and blocks the calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor (CGRPR), preventing the activity of CGRP-a protein that promotes inflammation and vasodilation in the brain, both of which are implicated in the onset and maintenance of migraine attacks-thereby reducing the likelihood and severity of migraine episodes.

name: Ajovy
description: Ajovy is prescribed for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults, helping to reduce the frequency and severity of both episodic and chronic migraine attacks.
mechanism_of_action: Ajovy is a monoclonal antibody that targets and binds to the calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) ligand, blocking its interaction with CGRP receptors; this inhibition prevents CGRP-induced vasodilation and inflammation in the brain, key processes believed to trigger migraine attacks, thereby reducing the likelihood and intensity of migraine.

name: Albuterol
description: Albuterol is used to treat or prevent bronchospasm (narrowing of the airways) in patients with asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchitis, emphysema, and other lung diseases, as well as to prevent exercise-induced bronchospasm.
mechanism_of_action: Albuterol is a selective beta2-adrenergic receptor agonist that works by stimulating beta2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, activating the Gs-adenylyl cyclase-cAMP signaling pathway, which leads to relaxation of airway smooth muscle and bronchodilation; this increases airflow and relieves symptoms such as wheezing and shortness of breath. Additionally, albuterol inhibits inflammatory cell activity in the airways by increasing intracellular cAMP, thereby reducing the release of inflammatory mediators and further contributing to its therapeutic effects.

name: Aldactone
description: Aldactone is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), heart failure (especially with reduced ejection fraction), edema (swelling) due to heart, liver, or kidney disease, primary hyperaldosteronism (a condition of excessive aldosterone production), and low potassium levels (hypokalemia); it is also used off-label for conditions such as hirsutism, female pattern hair loss, and adult acne.
mechanism_of_action: Aldactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that competitively blocks aldosterone from binding to its receptors in the distal renal tubules and collecting ducts, leading to increased excretion of sodium and water while retaining potassium; this antagonism reduces blood volume and vascular stiffness, lowers blood pressure, relieves fluid overload, and counters the effects of excess aldosterone in conditions like heart failure and hyperaldosteronism.

name: Alecensa
description: Alecensa is used to treat adults with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) that is positive for an abnormal anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene, specifically for metastatic (advanced) ALK-positive NSCLC and as adjuvant therapy to help prevent cancer recurrence after surgical removal of the tumor.
mechanism_of_action: Alecensa is a selective tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets and blocks the activity of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and, to a lesser extent, RET kinases; by inhibiting ALK, which is abnormally activated in certain NSCLC cells, Alecensa disrupts downstream signaling pathways responsible for tumor cell growth, proliferation, and survival, thereby slowing or stopping the progression of ALK-positive lung cancer.

name: Alendronate
description: Alendronate is used to treat and prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and men, osteoporosis caused by long-term corticosteroid use, and Paget’s disease of bone, helping to strengthen bones and reduce the risk of fractures.
mechanism_of_action: Alendronate is a bisphosphonate that binds to hydroxyapatite in bone and is taken up by osteoclasts during bone resorption; it inhibits farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase in the mevalonate pathway, disrupting osteoclast function and promoting their apoptosis, thereby reducing bone breakdown, increasing bone density, and lowering fracture risk.

name: Allegra
description: Allegra is used to relieve symptoms of seasonal allergies (hay fever) such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and is also indicated for chronic idiopathic urticaria, a condition characterized by persistent hives and itching in adults and children.
mechanism_of_action: Allegra (fexofenadine) is a second-generation antihistamine that selectively blocks peripheral histamine H1 receptors, preventing histamine from binding and triggering allergic symptoms such as inflammation, itching, and swelling, while not crossing the blood-brain barrier, thus minimizing sedation and central nervous system effects.

name: Allopurinol
description: Allopurinol is used to prevent gout attacks by lowering uric acid levels in the blood, treat recurrent kidney stones associated with high uric acid, and manage elevated uric acid in patients undergoing cancer chemotherapy (to prevent tumor lysis syndrome).
mechanism_of_action: Allopurinol is a purine analog and xanthine oxidase inhibitor; it and its active metabolite oxipurinol block the enzyme xanthine oxidase, preventing the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid, thereby reducing uric acid production and serum levels. This inhibition also increases the salvage of hypoxanthine and xanthine for nucleotide synthesis, which provides feedback inhibition of purine biosynthesis, further lowering uric acid formation.

name: Alprazolam
description: Alprazolam is primarily prescribed for the management of anxiety disorders, including generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) and panic disorder (with or without agoraphobia); it may also be used off-label for conditions such as depression, premenstrual syndrome, and insomnia.
mechanism_of_action: Alprazolam is a high-potency benzodiazepine that binds to a specific site on the GABA-A receptor complex in the central nervous system, acting as a positive allosteric modulator to enhance the inhibitory effect of the neurotransmitter GABA; this increases chloride ion influx into neurons, hyperpolarizing them and making them less excitable, which produces its anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, and anticonvulsant effects.

name: Amantadine
description: Amantadine is used to treat symptoms of Parkinson’s disease and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms (movement disorders), as well as for the prevention and treatment of influenza A virus infections, though resistance limits its current use for flu.
mechanism_of_action: Amantadine’s antiparkinsonian effects are thought to result from a combination of weak antagonism of NMDA-type glutamate receptors, increased dopamine release, inhibition of dopamine reuptake, and agonism at sigma-1 receptors, collectively enhancing dopaminergic signaling in the brain and reducing movement symptoms. As an antiviral, amantadine blocks the M2 ion channel protein of influenza A viruses, inhibiting viral uncoating and replication within host cells.

name: Ambien
description: Ambien is prescribed for the short-term treatment of insomnia, specifically to help adults who have difficulty falling asleep (sleep initiation), and its extended-release form (Ambien CR) can also help with staying asleep during the night.
mechanism_of_action: Ambien (zolpidem) is a non-benzodiazepine hypnotic that acts as a positive allosteric modulator at the benzodiazepine (BZ1/omega-1) site of the GABA-A receptor complex in the brain, enhancing the inhibitory effects of the neurotransmitter GABA by increasing chloride ion influx into neurons; this leads to neuronal hyperpolarization, decreased excitability, and rapid onset of sedation and sleep. Unlike benzodiazepines, zolpidem is structurally unrelated but shares similar pharmacological properties, producing its sedative effects with minimal anxiolytic, muscle relaxant, or anticonvulsant activity at therapeutic doses.

name: Amiodarone
description: Amiodarone is used to treat and prevent serious, life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation, especially when other antiarrhythmic medications are ineffective or cannot be tolerated.
mechanism_of_action: Amiodarone is primarily classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent that works by blocking cardiac potassium channels, thereby prolonging phase 3 repolarization of the cardiac action potential, which increases the refractory period and stabilizes heart rhythm. It also exhibits sodium channel blockade (reducing conduction velocity), noncompetitive alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptor antagonism (reducing sympathetic stimulation), and calcium channel blockade (decreasing intracellular calcium during contraction), resulting in broad antiarrhythmic effects across multiple cardiac tissues.

name: Amitriptyline
description: Amitriptyline is primarily prescribed for major depressive disorder in adults, but it is also widely used off-label to manage chronic pain conditions (such as neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, and arthritis-related pain), prevent migraine and tension-type headaches, and treat anxiety, insomnia, irritable bowel syndrome, and certain bladder pain syndromes.
mechanism_of_action: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that works by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine at presynaptic nerve terminals, increasing their levels in the brain and enhancing neurotransmission; it also blocks sodium, potassium, and NMDA ion channels at central and spinal levels, contributing to its pain-relieving effects, and has strong anticholinergic and sedative properties due to its affinity for muscarinic and histamine H1 receptors.

name: Amlodipine
description: Amlodipine is used alone or in combination with other medications to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) in adults and children aged 6 years and older, chronic stable angina (chest pain), vasospastic (Prinzmetal’s or variant) angina, and to reduce the risk of hospitalization for angina or coronary revascularization in patients with documented coronary artery disease without heart failure.
mechanism_of_action: Amlodipine is a long-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that selectively inhibits L-type calcium channels in vascular smooth muscle and cardiac muscle, reducing calcium influx into these cells; this leads to relaxation of vascular smooth muscle, vasodilation, and a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance, thereby lowering blood pressure. In angina, amlodipine decreases myocardial oxygen demand by reducing afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against) and prevents coronary artery spasm, improving blood flow to the heart muscle.

name: Amoxicillin
description: Amoxicillin is a widely used penicillin-type antibiotic indicated for the treatment of a variety of bacterial infections, including ear, nose, and throat infections (such as otitis media, tonsillitis, and pharyngitis), lower respiratory tract infections (such as pneumonia and bronchitis), sinusitis, urinary tract infections, skin and soft tissue infections, certain dental infections, and as part of combination therapy for Helicobacter pylori eradication in peptic ulcer disease; it is also used for prophylaxis of bacterial endocarditis and as an alternative for Lyme disease and anthrax post-exposure in specific circumstances.
mechanism_of_action: Amoxicillin is a broad-spectrum β-lactam antibiotic that works by binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) on susceptible bacteria, inhibiting the transpeptidation step of peptidoglycan synthesis in the bacterial cell wall; this disruption weakens the cell wall, leading to cell lysis and bacterial death (bactericidal effect). It is often combined with a β-lactamase inhibitor (such as clavulanic acid) to overcome bacterial resistance mechanisms that would otherwise inactivate amoxicillin.

name: Ampicillin
description: Ampicillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including meningitis, respiratory tract infections (such as pneumonia and bronchitis), sinusitis, throat infections, urinary tract infections, gastrointestinal infections (including those caused by Salmonella and Shigella), reproductive organ infections, and skin and soft tissue infections.

name: AndroGel
description: AndroGel is used as hormone replacement therapy to treat adult males with conditions resulting from a lack of natural testosterone, such as primary or secondary hypogonadism; it may also be used as part of gender-affirming hormone therapy for transgender men.
mechanism_of_action: AndroGel contains testosterone, which is absorbed through the skin and enters the bloodstream, where it binds to androgen receptors in target tissues; the testosterone-androgen receptor complex translocates to the cell nucleus, binds to specific DNA sequences, and regulates the transcription of genes responsible for the development and maintenance of male primary and secondary sexual characteristics, muscle mass, bone density, libido, mood, and other physiological effects.

name: Apixaban
description: Apixaban is an anticoagulant used to treat and prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, and prevent blood clots after hip or knee replacement surgery.
mechanism_of_action: Apixaban is a highly selective, direct factor Xa inhibitor that blocks both free and clot-bound factor Xa as well as prothrombinase activity, thereby preventing the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin in the coagulation cascade; this inhibition reduces thrombin generation, fibrin formation, and ultimately the development of blood clots, without requiring antithrombin III and without directly affecting platelet aggregation.

name: Arimidex
description: Arimidex is used as hormone therapy for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive early breast cancer in postmenopausal women, as a first-line treatment for hormone receptor-positive or hormone receptor-unknown locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer, and for advanced breast cancer in postmenopausal women whose disease has progressed following tamoxifen therapy.
mechanism_of_action: Arimidex is a non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor that works by reversibly binding to and inhibiting the aromatase enzyme, which is responsible for converting androgens to estrogens; this inhibition lowers estrogen levels in the body, thereby depriving hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells of the estrogen they need to grow and proliferate.

name: Aripiprazole
description: Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat a range of psychiatric and mood disorders, including schizophrenia in adults and adolescents, acute manic and mixed episodes associated with bipolar I disorder, as an adjunct for major depressive disorder, irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder, and Tourette’s disorder in children and adolescents.
mechanism_of_action: Aripiprazole acts as a partial agonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT1A receptors and as an antagonist at serotonin 5-HT2A receptors, modulating dopamine and serotonin activity in the brain. Specifically, it functions as a presynaptic D2 receptor agonist (reducing dopamine release) and a postsynaptic D2 receptor antagonist (blocking excessive dopamine signaling), thereby stabilizing dopamine neurotransmission and reducing symptoms of psychosis and mood disturbance without causing significant extrapyramidal side effects.

name: Apriso
description: Apriso is an extended-release oral capsule formulation of mesalamine used in adults to maintain remission of ulcerative colitis, a chronic inflammatory bowel disease, by helping to prevent flare-ups and keep symptoms from returning.
mechanism_of_action: Apriso (mesalamine) is an aminosalicylate that exerts a local anti-inflammatory effect on the colonic epithelial cells; while its precise mechanism is not fully understood, it is believed to inhibit the production of pro-inflammatory arachidonic acid metabolites (such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes) through both cyclooxygenase and lipoxygenase pathways, thereby reducing inflammation in the colon associated with ulcerative colitis.

name: Ascorbic acid
description: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is used to prevent and treat vitamin C deficiency, including scurvy, and is also taken as a dietary supplement when dietary intake is insufficient; it supports wound healing, enhances iron absorption from plant sources, maintains healthy skin, bones, teeth, and blood vessels, and is used as an antioxidant to protect cells from free radical damage.
mechanism_of_action: Ascorbic acid acts as a water-soluble antioxidant and enzyme cofactor; it is reversibly oxidized to dehydroascorbic acid in the body and participates in oxidation-reduction (redox) reactions, serving as a cofactor for enzymes involved in collagen synthesis, neurotransmitter production, and carnitine biosynthesis, while also enhancing iron absorption, supporting immune function, and protecting cellular components from oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals.

name: Aromasin
description: Aromasin is used to treat early and advanced hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in postmenopausal women, often as adjuvant therapy after initial treatment with tamoxifen, to lower the risk of cancer recurrence or slow the growth of cancer that needs estrogen to grow.
mechanism_of_action: Aromasin is a steroidal, irreversible aromatase inhibitor that selectively binds to and inactivates the aromatase enzyme, which is responsible for converting androgens into estrogens in postmenopausal women; by blocking this final step in estrogen biosynthesis, Aromasin markedly lowers estrogen levels in the body, depriving hormone receptor-positive breast cancer cells of the estrogen they require for growth and survival.

name: Aspirin
description: Aspirin is used to relieve mild to moderate pain, reduce fever, and decrease inflammation in conditions such as headaches, arthritis, muscle aches, and menstrual cramps; it is also used at low doses to lower the risk of heart attack, stroke, and blood clots in people with cardiovascular disease or risk factors, and to treat or prevent complications in certain rheumatologic and cardiovascular conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and modifies cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzymes by acetylating a serine residue, thereby blocking the synthesis of prostaglandins and thromboxane A2 from arachidonic acid; this results in analgesic, antipyretic, anti-inflammatory, and antiplatelet effects, with the irreversible inhibition of platelet thromboxane A2 production leading to its unique blood-thinning properties. Additionally, aspirin can trigger the production of anti-inflammatory lipid mediators known as aspirin-triggered lipoxins and resolvins.

name: Atarax
description: Atarax (hydroxyzine hydrochloride) is used to manage anxiety and tension associated with nervous and emotional conditions, as a sedative before and after general anesthesia, and to relieve itching (pruritus) from allergic skin conditions such as chronic urticaria, atopic dermatitis, and contact dermatoses.
mechanism_of_action: Atarax is a first-generation antihistamine that works by competitively blocking histamine H1 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract, blood vessels, and respiratory tract, thereby preventing the effects of histamine and reducing allergic symptoms; it also exhibits activity at muscarinic, serotonergic, and dopaminergic receptors in the brain, which contributes to its anxiolytic and sedative properties.

name: Atenolol
description: Atenolol is used alone or in combination with other medications to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), prevent angina (chest pain), and improve survival after a heart attack by reducing the risk of further cardiac events.
mechanism_of_action: Atenolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that works by selectively blocking beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, which decreases the effects of catecholamines (such as adrenaline), resulting in a slower heart rate, reduced force of heart contraction, and lowered blood pressure; this reduces the heart’s oxygen demand, helps prevent angina, and lowers the risk of complications after a heart attack. At higher doses, atenolol may also block beta-2 receptors, but its primary action is on beta-1 receptors in cardiac tissue.

name: Ativan
description: Ativan (lorazepam) is primarily used to manage anxiety disorders and provide short-term relief of anxiety symptoms, including anxiety associated with depression; it is also used for the short-term treatment of insomnia caused by anxiety or stress, to treat status epilepticus (a severe, prolonged seizure), and as a sedative before surgery.
mechanism_of_action: Ativan is a benzodiazepine that binds with high affinity to the benzodiazepine site on the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-A receptor complex in the brain, enhancing the effect of GABA (the main inhibitory neurotransmitter) by increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening; this results in neuronal hyperpolarization and decreased excitability, producing anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, and anticonvulsant effects.

name: Atomoxetine
description: Atomoxetine is primarily used to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children, adolescents, and adults, helping to improve attention, reduce impulsivity, and decrease hyperactivity.
mechanism_of_action: Atomoxetine is a highly selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that works by blocking the presynaptic norepinephrine transporter (NET), increasing norepinephrine levels in the synaptic cleft throughout the brain, particularly in the prefrontal cortex; it also modestly increases dopamine in this region by inhibiting its reuptake locally, but has little or no affinity for serotonin or dopamine transporters elsewhere. This enhancement of noradrenergic and dopaminergic signaling in the prefrontal cortex is thought to underlie its therapeutic effects on attention and impulse control in ADHD.

name: Atorvastatin
description: Atorvastatin is a statin medication used to lower elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the blood, primarily to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attack, stroke, angina, and the need for revascularization procedures in adults with high cholesterol, mixed dyslipidemia, or multiple cardiac risk factors; it is also indicated for treating various forms of hyperlipidemia, including familial hypercholesterolemia, and for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in at-risk patients.
mechanism_of_action: Atorvastatin is a selective, competitive inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis, which catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate; by blocking this step, atorvastatin reduces hepatic cholesterol synthesis, leading to upregulation of hepatic LDL receptors, increased clearance of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) from the bloodstream, and decreases in total cholesterol, LDL-C, very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (VLDL-C), and triglycerides, while modestly increasing high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C).

name: Augmentin
description: Augmentin is a prescription antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including sinusitis, pneumonia, ear infections (otitis media), bronchitis, urinary tract infections, skin and soft tissue infections, and infections caused by animal bites; it is often chosen when the causative bacteria may be resistant to standard penicillins or amoxicillin alone.
mechanism_of_action: Augmentin is a combination of amoxicillin, a broad-spectrum β-lactam antibiotic that kills bacteria by inhibiting the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall through binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), and clavulanic acid, a β-lactamase inhibitor that protects amoxicillin from degradation by bacterial β-lactamase enzymes, thereby extending its spectrum of activity to include β-lactamase–producing, resistant bacteria.

name: Avonex
description: Avonex (interferon beta-1a) is used to treat relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (MS), including clinically isolated syndrome, relapsing-remitting MS, and active secondary progressive MS, helping to reduce the frequency of relapses and slow the progression of physical disability.
mechanism_of_action: Avonex is a recombinant form of human interferon beta that binds to specific cell-surface receptors, initiating intracellular signaling cascades that modulate immune system activity; although the precise mechanism in MS is not fully understood, it is believed to reduce inflammation in the central nervous system by altering the balance of pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines, decreasing immune cell activity against myelin, and suppressing the autoimmune response that leads to nerve damage in MS.

name: Azithromycin
description: Azithromycin is a broad-spectrum macrolide antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections (such as pneumonia, bronchitis, and sinusitis), ear infections, skin and soft tissue infections, certain sexually transmitted infections (like chlamydia and gonorrhea), and as prophylaxis or treatment for Mycobacterium avium complex in immunocompromised patients; it is also used off-label for conditions such as Lyme disease and as long-term prophylaxis for recurrent chest infections.
mechanism_of_action: Azithromycin binds to the 23S rRNA of the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, inhibiting the translocation and assembly steps of protein synthesis, which prevents bacteria from producing essential proteins and thus halts their growth; it is primarily bacteriostatic but can be bactericidal at higher concentrations or against certain organisms.

name: Bacitracin
description: Bacitracin is a topical antibiotic used to prevent and treat minor skin infections resulting from small cuts, scrapes, or burns; it is also available in ophthalmic formulations for eye infections and, less commonly, as an intramuscular injection for certain severe infections in infants.
alternate_names: neosporin (when combined with neomycin and polymyxin B)
mechanism_of_action: Bacitracin is a cyclic polypeptide antibiotic that exerts its antibacterial effect by binding to and sequestering undecaprenyl pyrophosphate (C55PP), a membrane carrier lipid essential for peptidoglycan synthesis in bacterial cell walls; this action blocks the dephosphorylation and recycling of C55PP, thereby inhibiting the transport of cell wall building blocks and ultimately preventing bacterial cell wall synthesis, leading to cell lysis and death.

name: Baclofen
description: Baclofen is a skeletal muscle relaxant used to treat spasticity (muscle stiffness and tightness) and muscle pain in conditions such as multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injuries, and other spinal cord diseases, helping to reduce the frequency and severity of muscle spasms and improve mobility.
mechanism_of_action: Baclofen is a selective agonist at the GABABB receptor, primarily in the spinal cord and brain, where it inhibits the release of excitatory neurotransmitters presynaptically and enhances inhibitory signals postsynaptically; this dual action reduces neuronal excitability, leading to decreased muscle spasticity and associated pain.

name: Bactroban
description: Bactroban (mupirocin) is a topical antibiotic used to treat superficial skin infections such as impetigo, folliculitis, and other primary and secondary skin infections caused by susceptible bacteria, particularly Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA) and Streptococcus pyogenes; it may also be used to eradicate nasal carriage of MRSA and to prevent infection in minor wounds, cuts, and abrasions.
mechanism_of_action: Bactroban (mupirocin) works by specifically and reversibly inhibiting bacterial isoleucyl-tRNA synthetase, an enzyme essential for incorporating the amino acid isoleucine into bacterial proteins; this inhibition blocks bacterial protein synthesis, leading to bacteriostatic effects at low concentrations and bactericidal activity with prolonged exposure or higher concentrations.

name: Baqsimi
description: Baqsimi is a prescription intranasal glucagon powder used to treat severe hypoglycemia (very low blood sugar) in people with diabetes ages 4 years and older, especially when the person is unable to eat, loses consciousness, or is having a seizure.
mechanism_of_action: Baqsimi contains glucagon, which increases blood glucose concentration by activating hepatic glucagon receptors, stimulating the breakdown of glycogen (glycogenolysis) and the release of glucose from the liver into the bloodstream; this action requires adequate hepatic glycogen stores to be effective.

name: Basaglar
description: Basaglar is a long-acting insulin used to control high blood sugar in adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes, and in children aged 6 years and older with type 1 diabetes. It is not approved for use in children with type 2 diabetes or in children younger than 6 years with type 1 diabetes. Basaglar is not used to treat diabetic ketoacidosis.
mechanism_of_action: Basaglar (insulin glargine) is a long-acting insulin analog. After subcutaneous injection, it forms microprecipitates in the subcutaneous tissue, releasing small amounts of insulin glargine slowly and evenly over approximately 24 hours with no pronounced peak. It lowers blood glucose by stimulating peripheral glucose uptake, inhibiting hepatic glucose production, inhibiting liplysis and proteolysis, and enhanching protein synthesis.

name: Belbuca
description: Belbuca is a prescription medication used for the management of severe, persistent, chronic pain that requires daily, around-the-clock, long-term opioid treatment and for which alternative treatment options (such as non-opioid analgesics or immediate-release opioids) are ineffective, not tolerated, or inadequate. It is not indicated for use as an as-needed (prn) pain reliever or for minor or occasional pain.
mechanism_of_action: Belbuca contains buprenorphine, a partial opioid agonist. It binds to opioid receptors in the central nervous system, producing analgesia (pain relief) and, at higher doses, can also act as an opioid antagonist. This partial agonist activity provides effective pain relief with a lower risk of respiratory depression compared to full opioid agonists, but it still carries significant risks of addiction, abuse, and misuse. The medication is administered as a buccal film placed inside the cheek, where it adheres to the mucosa and dissolves to deliver buprenorphine systemically

name: Benadryl
description: Benadryl is a first-generation antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of allergies and the common cold-such as sneezing, runny nose, watery eyes, itchy eyes/nose/throat, hives, skin rash, and itching. It is also used to treat or prevent motion sickness, manage insomnia in adults, alleviate symptoms of mild Parkinsonism and drug-induced movement disorders, and provide short-term relief of cough and cold symptoms.
mechanism_of_action: Benadryl works by competitively blocking histamine H1 receptors on various tissues, including those in the respiratory tract, blood vessels, skin, and central nervous system. This antagonism prevents histamine-a chemical released during allergic reactions-from binding to its receptors, thereby reducing symptoms like itching, sneezing, and runny nose. Diphenhydramine also has significant anticholinergic (drying) and sedative effects, which contribute to its use as a sleep aid and its side effect profile.

name: Benazepril
description: Benazepril is primarily used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) in adults and children aged 6 years and older. Lowering blood pressure helps reduce the risk of stroke, heart attack, and kidney problems. It may also be prescribed for other conditions, such as heart failure or chronic kidney disease, as determined by your healthcare provider.
mechanism_of_action: Benazepril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. After being converted in the body to its active form, benazeprilat, it blocks the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II-a hormone that causes blood vessels to constrict and stimulates aldosterone secretion, leading to sodium and water retention. By inhibiting this process, benazepril relaxes blood vessels, reduces blood pressure, and decreases the workload on the heart.

name: Benicar
description: Benicar (olmesartan medoxomil) is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) in adults and children aged 6 years and older, helping to reduce the risk of stroke, heart attack, and kidney problems by lowering blood pressure.
mechanism_of_action: Benicar is a prodrug that is rapidly converted in the body to olmesartan, a selective angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) that specifically inhibits the binding of angiotensin II to the AT1 receptor in vascular smooth muscle, thereby preventing vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion, resulting in relaxation of blood vessels and reduced blood pressure; this effect is independent of the pathway by which angiotensin II is synthesized.

name: Benlysta
description: Benlysta (belimumab) is used as an add-on therapy for adults and children aged 5 years and older with active systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and active lupus nephritis (lupus-related kidney inflammation) who are already receiving standard treatments such as corticosteroids or immunosuppressants.
mechanism_of_action: Benlysta is a human monoclonal antibody that selectively binds to and inhibits B-lymphocyte stimulator (BLyS, also known as BAFF), a protein essential for B cell survival and maturation; by blocking BLyS from binding to its receptors on B cells, Benlysta reduces the survival of autoreactive B cells, decreases the production of autoantibodies, and dampens the abnormal immune response that drives lupus activity.

name: Bentyl
description: Bentyl (dicyclomine) is used to treat irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and related functional bowel disorders by relieving intestinal muscle spasms, abdominal pain, and cramping associated with these conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Bentyl is an anticholinergic and antispasmodic agent that works by competitively blocking acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal tract, thereby relaxing intestinal smooth muscle, reducing involuntary contractions, and alleviating the cramping and discomfort of IBS.

name: Benzonatate
description: Benzonatate is a non-narcotic oral antitussive (cough suppressant) used to relieve cough associated with acute and chronic respiratory conditions, such as the common cold, bronchitis, pneumonia, and other respiratory tract infections in patients over 10 years of age.
mechanism_of_action: Benzonatate acts peripherally by anesthetizing (numbing) the stretch receptors and vagal sensory nerve fibers in the respiratory passages, lungs, and pleura, which are involved in triggering the cough reflex; this is achieved through its local anesthetic-like inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels (including Nav1.7), thereby reducing the transmission of cough impulses to the medullary cough center and suppressing the urge to cough.

name: Benztropine
description: Benztropine is used as an adjunct therapy to manage symptoms of Parkinson’s disease and to control extrapyramidal symptoms (such as tremors, rigidity, and involuntary movements) caused by antipsychotic medications or other medical conditions affecting movement.
mechanism_of_action: Benztropine is a centrally acting anticholinergic and antihistaminic agent that primarily blocks muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (especially M1) in the brain, reducing the effects of acetylcholine and restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the basal ganglia to improve movement symptoms; it also inhibits dopamine reuptake, modestly increasing dopaminergic activity, and has some antagonism at histamine H1 receptors.

name: Betamethasone
description: Betamethasone is a potent corticosteroid used to treat a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions. Topically, it is prescribed for skin disorders such as eczema, psoriasis, dermatitis, and allergic reactions to reduce itching, redness, and swelling. Systemically (by injection or orally), it is used to manage severe allergic reactions, certain autoimmune diseases, asthma exacerbations, arthritis, and to promote fetal lung maturity in preterm labor.
mechanism_of_action: Betamethasone is a synthetic glucocorticoid that binds to intracellular glucocorticoid receptors, altering gene expression to suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and mediators, inhibit leukocyte migration, decrease capillary permeability, and stabilize cell membranes, thereby reducing inflammation, immune responses, and associated symptoms. It also inhibits phospholipase A2, decreasing the synthesis of arachidonic acid derivatives (prostaglandins and leukotrienes), and promotes the expression of anti-inflammatory proteins such as interleukin-10.

name: Bevacizumab
description: Bevacizumab is used in combination with chemotherapy to treat various cancers, including metastatic colorectal cancer, non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer, glioblastoma (a type of brain tumor), metastatic renal cell carcinoma, cervical cancer, ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal cancers, and is sometimes used off-label for other malignancies and eye diseases.
mechanism_of_action: Bevacizumab is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody that selectively binds to and neutralizes vascular endothelial growth factor A (VEGF-A), a key protein that stimulates angiogenesis (the formation of new blood vessels); by inhibiting VEGF-A, bevacizumab prevents the growth of new blood vessels that supply tumors, thereby reducing tumor vascularization, slowing tumor growth, and potentially causing tumor shrinkage.

name: Biktarvy
description: Biktarvy is a once-daily, oral prescription medication used to treat HIV-1 infection in adults and children weighing at least 14 kg who have either never taken HIV-1 medicines before or are replacing their current HIV-1 regimen while virologically suppressed (HIV-1 RNA <50 copies/mL) with no known resistance to its components; it is not used for HIV prevention.
mechanism_of_action: Biktarvy combines three antiretroviral agents with complementary mechanisms: bictegravir, an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), blocks the HIV-1 integrase enzyme and prevents viral DNA from integrating into the host genome; emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide are nucleoside/nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) that inhibit HIV reverse transcriptase, resulting in premature termination of viral DNA synthesis-together, these actions suppress HIV replication, reduce viral load, and help restore immune function.

name: Biotin
description: Biotin (vitamin B7, also known as vitamin H) is primarily used to prevent and treat biotin deficiency, which can occur due to genetic disorders, certain medical conditions, or malnutrition; it is also commonly marketed and used for hair loss, brittle nails, and to support healthy skin, though robust evidence for these cosmetic uses in healthy individuals is lacking.
mechanism_of_action: Biotin acts as a coenzyme for several carboxylase enzymes involved in key metabolic processes, including the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA and pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which are essential for the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and amino acids. It is converted to its active form by biotinidase and attaches to specific lysine residues on enzymes, enabling critical reactions in energy production, fatty acid synthesis, and gluconeogenesis. Biotin also plays roles in cell signaling, gene regulation (epigenetics), and supports healthy nervous system function by contributing to myelination and neuronal health.

name: Bisoprolol
description: Bisoprolol is used alone or in combination with other medications to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), and is also prescribed for certain heart-related conditions such as heart failure, angina, and tachyarrhythmias.
mechanism_of_action: Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-1 adrenergic blocker that works by competitively and selectively inhibiting beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart and kidneys, thereby reducing the effects of catecholamines (such as adrenaline) on heart rate and contractility, lowering cardiac output, and suppressing renin secretion; this leads to decreased blood pressure and reduced workload on the heart, with minimal effect on beta-2 receptors at therapeutic doses.

name: Botox
description: Botox (onabotulinumtoxinA) is used both cosmetically and medically. Cosmetically, it is FDA-approved to temporarily reduce the appearance of facial wrinkles such as glabellar lines (frown lines), crow’s feet, and forehead lines, and is also used off-label for jawline slimming, eyebrow lifting, and other facial enhancement. Medically, Botox is used to treat chronic migraine, cervical dystonia (neck muscle spasms), spasticity, overactive bladder, urinary incontinence, excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis), strabismus (crossed eyes), blepharospasm (eyelid spasms), and other conditions involving abnormal muscle activity or glandular secretion.
mechanism_of_action: Botox is a neurotoxin that binds to presynaptic cholinergic nerve terminals, is internalized into the neuron, and cleaves SNARE proteins (specifically SNAP-25), thereby blocking the release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction and autonomic nerve endings; this inhibition prevents muscle contraction and glandular secretion, resulting in temporary muscle paralysis or reduced gland activity until new nerve terminals regenerate.

name: Breo Ellipta
description: Breo Ellipta is a once-daily inhaled medication used for the long-term maintenance treatment of asthma in adults and children ages 5 or 6 years and older (varies by country), and for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including to improve lung function and reduce the risk of COPD exacerbations; it is not a rescue inhaler and should not be used for acute symptom relief.
mechanism_of_action: Breo Ellipta contains two active ingredients: fluticasone furoate, an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) that reduces airway inflammation by inhibiting multiple types of inflammatory cells and mediators, and vilanterol, a long-acting beta2-adrenergic agonist (LABA) that relaxes bronchial smooth muscle through selective stimulation of beta2-receptors, leading to bronchodilation; together, these actions decrease airway inflammation and keep airways open to improve breathing and reduce the frequency of asthma and COPD flare-ups.

name: Brilinta
description: Brilinta (ticagrelor) is an oral antiplatelet medication used to lower the risk of heart attack, stroke, or cardiovascular death in people with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), a history of heart attack, coronary artery disease (CAD) with high risk factors, or after placement of a coronary stent, and to reduce the risk of stroke and death in adults with a blockage or decreased blood flow in an artery supplying the brain.
mechanism_of_action: Brilinta is a direct-acting, reversible P2Y12 receptor antagonist that inhibits platelet activation and aggregation by blocking the binding of adenosine diphosphate (ADP) to the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, thereby preventing platelets from clumping together and forming blood clots that can block arteries and cause heart attacks or strokes.

name: Briomonidine
description: Brimonidine is primarily used to lower intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension, helping to prevent optic nerve damage and vision loss; it is also available in lower-strength, over-the-counter formulations to relieve eye redness due to minor irritation, and as a topical gel for the treatment of persistent facial redness (erythema) in adults with rosacea.
mechanism_of_action: Brimonidine is a highly selective alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist that lowers intraocular pressure by both reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow in the eye; when used for eye redness or facial erythema, it acts as a peripheral vasoconstrictor by stimulating alpha-2 receptors on blood vessels, leading to constriction and reduced blood flow, thereby decreasing redness.

name: Briviact
description: Briviact (brivaracetam) is a prescription anticonvulsant used to treat partial-onset (focal) seizures in adults, adolescents, and children as young as 1 month old, either alone or in combination with other seizure medications.
mechanism_of_action: Briviact is a third-generation antiepileptic drug that exerts its effect by binding with high affinity to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A) in the brain, a protein involved in regulating neurotransmitter release; this selective binding modulates synaptic transmission and stabilizes neuronal activity, thereby reducing the likelihood of the abnormal electrical activity that causes seizures.

name: Budesonide
description: Budesonide is a corticosteroid used to treat a variety of inflammatory conditions including asthma, COPD, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, microscopic colitis, allergic rhinitis (hay fever), nasal polyps, eosinophilic esophagitis, and Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy).
mechanism_of_action: Budesonide is a potent glucocorticoid receptor agonist that works by binding to intracellular glucocorticoid receptors, altering gene expression to suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and mediators, reduce leukocyte migration, inhibit activation of inflammatory cells (such as eosinophils, mast cells, neutrophils, T-lymphocytes, and macrophages), and decrease capillary permeability; this results in a strong local anti-inflammatory effect in the airways, gastrointestinal tract, or nasal mucosa, depending on the route of administration.

name: Bumex
description: Bumex (bumetanide) is a potent loop diuretic (water pill) used to treat fluid retention (edema) associated with congestive heart failure, liver disease (such as cirrhosis), kidney disease (including nephrotic syndrome), and other conditions that cause excess fluid buildup.
mechanism_of_action: Bumex acts primarily in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney, where it inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption, leading to increased excretion of sodium, chloride, potassium, and water in the urine; this results in rapid and significant diuresis and reduction of fluid overload, with additional minor action in the proximal tubule but minimal effect on the distal tubule.

name: Buprenorphine
description: Buprenorphine is primarily used to treat opioid use disorder (OUD), helping to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings in people dependent on opioids such as heroin, oxycodone, or fentanyl; it is also prescribed for the management of moderate to severe pain when alternative treatments are inadequate.
mechanism_of_action: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu-opioid receptor, where it binds with high affinity but activates the receptor less than full agonists, producing a ceiling effect for respiratory depression and euphoria, and acts as an antagonist at the kappa-opioid receptor; this unique pharmacology diminishes opioid withdrawal and cravings, blocks the effects of other opioids, lowers the risk of misuse and overdose, and provides analgesia for pain management.

name: Bupropion
description: Bupropion is used to treat major depressive disorder (MDD) and seasonal affective disorder (SAD), and is also approved as an aid to smoking cessation; it is additionally used off-label for conditions such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), antidepressant-induced sexual dysfunction, obesity (in combination with naltrexone), and stimulant use disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Bupropion is a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) that works by weakly inhibiting the neuronal reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine via blockade of the norepinephrine transporter (NET) and dopamine transporter (DAT), thereby increasing the concentration of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft and enhancing their activity in the brain; it has minimal or no effect on serotonin reuptake and does not significantly interact with histamine, adrenergic, cholinergic, or serotonin receptors.

name: Buspar
description: Buspirone (formerly sold under the brand name Buspar) is primarily used to treat generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) and to relieve symptoms of anxiety, such as fear, tension, irritability, dizziness, and pounding heartbeat.It is sometimes used off-label as an adjunct in depression, for sexual dysfunction, and other psychiatric or neurological conditions, but its main approved indication is anxiety disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Buspirone is an azapirone anxiolytic that acts primarily as a partial agonist at serotonin 5-HT1A receptors (with high affinity), modulating serotonergic activity in the brain’s anxiety and fear circuits; it also has weak affinity for dopamine D2 receptors (antagonist) and minimal effect on other neurotransmitter systems, but does not interact with GABA receptors, distinguishing it from benzodiazepines. The clinical anxiolytic effect is believed to result from increased serotonergic activity in the amygdala and related brain regions, and buspirone does not cause sedation, muscle relaxation, or dependence typical of benzodiazepines.

name: Bystolic
description: Bystolic (nebivolol) is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) in adults, which helps lower the risk of stroke and heart attack; it may be used alone or in combination with other antihypertensive agents.
mechanism_of_action: Bystolic is a highly selective beta-1 adrenergic receptor blocker that lowers blood pressure by slowing the heart rate and reducing the force of heart contractions, and it uniquely stimulates endothelial nitric oxide synthase via beta-3 agonism, increasing nitric oxide production and causing vasodilation; at higher doses, or in slow metabolizers, it may also block beta-2 receptors.

name: Cabenuva
description: Cabenuva is a long-acting, injectable prescription regimen used to treat HIV-1 infection in adults and adolescents aged 12 years and older who weigh at least 35 kg (77 lbs), specifically for people who are virologically suppressed (HIV-1 RNA <50 copies/mL) and stable on their current antiretroviral therapy, with no history of treatment failure or known resistance to its components.
mechanism_of_action: Cabenuva contains two antiretroviral agents with complementary mechanisms. Cabotegravir is an integrase strand transfer inhibitor that blocks HIV integrase, preventing the integration of viral DNA into the host genome, a critical step in the HIV replication cycle. Rilpivirine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) that binds to reverse transcriptase, inhibiting the enzyme and thereby preventing the conversion of viral RNA into DNA, which is necessary for HIV replication.

name: Calcitriol
description: Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D3 and is used to treat and prevent low calcium levels (hypocalcemia) and bone disease in patients with chronic kidney disease, secondary hyperparathyroidism (excess parathyroid hormone), hypoparathyroidism (low parathyroid hormone), and certain other conditions such as rickets, osteomalacia, and osteoporosis; it is also used topically for mild to moderate plaque psoriasis.
mechanism_of_action: Calcitriol is a hormonally active vitamin D analog that binds to vitamin D receptors (VDR) in the intestines, kidneys, bones, and parathyroid glands, acting as a transcription factor to increase the expression of proteins involved in calcium and phosphate absorption; it raises blood calcium levels by promoting intestinal absorption of dietary calcium, increasing renal tubular reabsorption of calcium, and stimulating the release of calcium from bone through osteoclast activation, while also suppressing parathyroid hormone (PTH) synthesis.

name: Candesartan
description: Candesartan is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) in adults and children aged 1 to 16 years, and is also prescribed for adults with heart failure to reduce the risk of hospitalization and death related to heart problems.
mechanism_of_action: Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) administered as the prodrug candesartan cilexetil, which is rapidly converted to its active form in the body; it selectively blocks angiotensin II from binding to the AT1 receptor in vascular smooth muscle and the adrenal glands, thereby preventing vasoconstriction and aldosterone secretion, resulting in relaxed blood vessels, reduced blood pressure, and decreased workload on the hear.

name: Caplyta
description: Caplyta (lumateperone) is a prescription oral capsule used to treat adults with schizophrenia and depressive episodes associated with bipolar I or II disorder, either alone or in combination with mood stabilizers such as lithium or valproate.
mechanism_of_action: Caplyta is an atypical (second-generation) antipsychotic that modulates neurotransmitter activity in the brain by antagonizing serotonin 5-HT2A receptors, partially agonizing presynaptic and antagonizing postsynaptic dopamine D2 receptors, blocking serotonin reuptake, and enhancing glutamate activity at NMDA receptors; these combined actions help balance serotonin, dopamine, and glutamate signaling, which are implicated in the symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar depression.

name: Carbamazepine
description: Carbamazepine is primarily used to treat epilepsy (various types of seizures), trigeminal neuralgia (a severe facial nerve pain), and as an extended-release formulation (Equetro), it is also approved for managing acute manic and mixed episodes in bipolar I disorder.
mechanism_of_action: Carbamazepine acts mainly by binding to and stabilizing the inactivated state of voltage-gated sodium channels in neuronal membranes, thereby inhibiting repetitive and sustained neuronal firing and reducing abnormal electrical activity in the brain; it may also modulate calcium channels and neurotransmitter release, and has additional effects on serotonin and other neurotransmitter systems, though these are less well understood.

name: Carvedilol
description: Carvedilol is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), heart failure, and left ventricular dysfunction following a heart attack, helping to lower the risk of hospitalization and death from heart-related causes.
mechanism_of_action: Carvedilol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic blocker (blocks both β1 and β2 receptors) and an alpha-1 adrenergic blocker; by inhibiting these receptors, it reduces the effects of catecholamines (such as adrenaline), leading to decreased heart rate and contractility, vasodilation, and reduced peripheral vascular resistance, which together lower blood pressure, decrease cardiac workload, and improve heart function in heart failure and after myocardial infarction.

name: Cefazolin
description: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including skin and soft tissue infections, respiratory tract infections (such as pneumonia), urinary tract infections, bone and joint infections, biliary tract infections, genital infections, blood infections (sepsis), and endocarditis; it is also commonly used before, during, and after surgery to prevent surgical site infections.
mechanism_of_action: Cefazolin works by binding to specific penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) inside the bacterial cell wall, inhibiting the final stage of peptidoglycan synthesis required for cell wall integrity; this disruption leads to bacterial cell lysis and death, making cefazolin bactericidal against susceptible organisms.

name: Cefdinir
description: Cefdinir is an oral, broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a variety of mild to moderate bacterial infections in adults and children, including community-acquired pneumonia, acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis, acute maxillary sinusitis, pharyngitis/tonsillitis (including strep throat), acute otitis media (middle ear infection), and uncomplicated skin and skin structure infections.
mechanism_of_action: Cefdinir is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that works by binding to and inhibiting penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) in bacterial cell walls, thereby blocking the final step of peptidoglycan synthesis, which weakens the cell wall and leads to bacterial cell lysis and death; it is bactericidal against a broad range of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

name: Cefixime
description: Cefixime is a third-generation oral cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including infections of the ears (otitis media), throat (pharyngitis, tonsillitis), sinuses, respiratory tract (such as bronchitis and pneumonia), urinary tract, and uncomplicated gonorrhea; it is also effective for certain skin and soft tissue infections and is sometimes used for typhoid fever.
mechanism_of_action: Cefixime acts by binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) in bacterial cell walls, inhibiting the final transpeptidation step in peptidoglycan synthesis, which disrupts cell wall formation and leads to bacterial cell lysis and death; this bactericidal action is effective against a broad range of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.

name: Ceftriaxone
description: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a wide range of serious bacterial infections, including pneumonia, meningitis, middle ear infections (otitis media), urinary tract infections, skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections, intra-abdominal infections, gonorrhea, pelvic inflammatory disease, septicemia (blood infections), and is also commonly used before or after surgery to prevent infections.
mechanism_of_action: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum, third-generation cephalosporin that works by selectively and irreversibly binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), particularly transpeptidases, in bacterial cell membranes, thereby inhibiting the final stage of peptidoglycan synthesis required for bacterial cell wall integrity; this disruption leads to defective cell walls, bacterial cell lysis, and death. It remains active against many beta-lactamase–producing bacteria and is bactericidal in action.

name: Celebrex
description: Celebrex (celecoxib) is a prescription nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain and inflammation associated with conditions such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (in children 2 years and older), acute pain in adults, and primary dysmenorrhea (menstrual pain); it is also approved for reducing the number of colon polyps in people with familial adenomatous polyposis.
mechanism_of_action: Celebrex is a highly selective inhibitor of cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), an enzyme responsible for the synthesis of prostaglandins that mediate pain and inflammation; by selectively blocking COX-2 while sparing COX-1, celecoxib reduces inflammation and pain with a lower risk of gastrointestinal side effects compared to nonselective NSAIDs, which inhibit both COX-1 and COX-2.

name: Cialis
description: Cialis (tadalafil) is prescribed to treat erectile dysfunction (ED), benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and the combination of ED and BPH symptoms in adult males. It is also available under a different brand (Adcirca) for pulmonary arterial hypertension, but Cialis itself is not used for this purpose.
mechanism_of_action: Cialis is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor that works by blocking the PDE5 enzyme, which leads to increased levels of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in smooth muscle cells. In the penis, this results in relaxation of smooth muscle and increased blood flow during sexual stimulation, facilitating erection; in the prostate and bladder, it relaxes smooth muscle to improve urinary symptoms of BPH.

name: Ciprofloxacin
description: Cipro (ciprofloxacin) is a broad-spectrum fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including urinary tract infections (UTIs), respiratory tract infections (such as bronchitis and pneumonia), skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections, infectious diarrhea, intra-abdominal infections (often with metronidazole), certain sexually transmitted infections (such as gonorrhea), and is also approved for treating or preventing anthrax exposure.
mechanism_of_action: Ciprofloxacin is a bactericidal antibiotic that works by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, enzymes essential for DNA replication, transcription, repair, and recombination; this inhibition disrupts bacterial cell division and leads to cell death, making it especially potent against gram-negative bacteria and some gram-positive organisms.

name: Clarithomycin
description: Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis, pharyngitis, tonsillitis, skin and soft tissue infections, ear infections (acute otitis media), and to both treat and prevent disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections, especially in people with HIV. It is also used in combination with other medications to eradicate Helicobacter pylori (which causes ulcers), and may be prescribed for other infections such as Lyme disease, cryptosporidiosis, cat scratch disease, Legionnaires’ disease, and pertussis.
mechanism_of_action: Clarithromycin works by binding to the 23S rRNA of the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, inhibiting protein synthesis by blocking the translocation of aminoacyl-tRNA and polypeptide chain elongation, which prevents bacteria from multiplying and ultimately leads to their death; this mechanism is similar to other macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin.

name: Claritin
description: Claritin is an over-the-counter antihistamine used to temporarily relieve symptoms of hay fever and other upper respiratory allergies, such as runny nose, sneezing, itchy or watery eyes, and itching of the nose or throat; it can also be used to treat hives and itching due to chronic urticaria.
mechanism_of_action: Claritin (loratadine) is a long-acting, second-generation, non-sedating antihistamine that selectively and competitively blocks peripheral histamine H1-receptors, thereby decreasing vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, and sensory nerve activation caused by histamine, which relieves allergy symptoms without significant sedation because it does not cross the blood-brain barrier.

name: Clindamycin
description: Clindamycin is an antibiotic used to treat a wide range of serious bacterial infections caused by susceptible anaerobic bacteria and certain aerobic gram-positive bacteria, including lower respiratory tract infections (such as pneumonia and lung abscess), skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections (including osteomyelitis), septicemia, intra-abdominal infections (such as peritonitis and abscesses), gynecological infections (such as endometritis and pelvic cellulitis), dental infections, and as a topical treatment for severe acne; it is also used for prophylaxis in surgical and dental procedures, and as an alternative in patients allergic to penicillins.
mechanism_of_action: Clindamycin is a lincosamide antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 23S rRNA of the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, blocking peptide chain initiation and elongation, which impedes ribosomal assembly and translation; this action is generally bacteriostatic but can be bactericidal against some organisms and concentrations.

name: Clonazepam
description: Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine medication primarily used to treat certain types of seizure disorders (epilepsy), including absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, as well as panic disorder (with or without agoraphobia); it is also used off-label for anxiety disorders, movement disorders such as restless legs syndrome, REM sleep behavior disorder, and as adjunct therapy for acute mania and other conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Clonazepam is a high-potency, long-acting benzodiazepine that acts as a positive allosteric modulator at the benzodiazepine site of the GABAAA receptor in the central nervous system; by enhancing the affinity of GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter, for its receptor, clonazepam increases the frequency of chloride channel opening, leading to hyperpolarization of neurons and decreased neuronal excitability-this results in anticonvulsant, anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, and hypnotic effects.

name: Clonidine
description: Clonidine is primarily used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), but it is also prescribed for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), management of withdrawal symptoms from opioids, alcohol, nicotine, and benzodiazepines, severe cancer pain (as an adjunct), Tourette syndrome (for tics), menopausal hot flashes, migraine prophylaxis, spasticity, anxiety, insomnia, and several other off-label conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Clonidine is a centrally acting, selective alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist that primarily stimulates presynaptic alpha-2a receptors in the brainstem (notably the locus coeruleus), resulting in reduced sympathetic outflow from the central nervous system; this decreases norepinephrine release, lowers peripheral vascular resistance, slows heart rate, and reduces blood pressure. Additionally, clonidine’s action on imidazoline receptors and its modulation of pain transmission in the spinal cord contribute to its effects in pain management and other indications.

name: Clopidogrel
description: Additionally, clonidine’s action on imidazoline receptors and its modulation of pain transmission in the spinal cord contribute to its effects in pain management and other indications.
mechanism_of_action: Clopidogrel is an inactive prodrug that is metabolized in the liver to its active form, which irreversibly binds to the platelet P2Y12 adenosine diphosphate (ADP) receptor; this blocks ADP-mediated activation of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex, thereby inhibiting platelet aggregation and reducing the formation of harmful blood clots for the lifespan of the platelet (7–10 days).

name: Clotrimazole
description: Clotrimazole is an antifungal medication used to treat a wide range of fungal and yeast infections, including athlete’s foot (tinea pedis), ringworm (tinea corporis), jock itch (tinea cruris), fungal nail infections, infected nappy rash, sweat rash (intertrigo), oral and vaginal candidiasis (thrush), pityriasis versicolor, and other skin infections caused by dermatophytes or Candida species.
