mechanism_of_action: Clotrimazole is an imidazole antifungal that works by inhibiting the fungal enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial for the synthesis of ergosterol, an essential component of the fungal cell membrane. By blocking ergosterol production, clotrimazole disrupts the integrity and function of the fungal cell membrane, leading to increased membrane permeability, impaired cellular processes, and ultimately the inhibition of fungal growth or cell death. At higher concentrations, clotrimazole may also be fungicidal. Additionally, it has secondary effects such as inhibition of calcium channels and depletion of intracellular calcium, but its primary action is on ergosterol synthesis.

name: Codeine
description: Codeine is an opioid medication used to treat mild to moderate pain and to suppress dry, irritating coughs; it is also sometimes used in combination with other drugs (such as acetaminophen, aspirin, or ibuprofen) for more severe pain, and may be included in certain cold and flu preparations to relieve cough and other symptoms.
mechanism_of_action: Codeine is a weak opioid agonist that exerts its effects primarily after being metabolized in the liver by the enzyme CYP2D6 into morphine, which then binds to mu-opioid receptors in the central nervous system to inhibit pain signal transmission and suppress the cough reflex; codeine also has direct, though weaker, agonist activity at mu-, kappa-, and delta-opioid receptors, and its metabolites (such as codeine-6-glucuronide) may contribute to its analgesic effects. This modulation of pain and cough occurs through decreased neurotransmitter release and hyperpolarization of neurons, resulting in reduced pain perception and cough.

name: Colace
description: Colace is an over-the-counter stool softener used to treat or prevent occasional constipation, especially in situations where straining should be avoided (such as after surgery, heart attack, or during pregnancy).
mechanism_of_action: Colace (docusate) acts as a surfactant in the intestines, reducing the surface tension of stool and allowing water and fats to penetrate and mix with the fecal mass, which increases the water content of the stool, making it softer and easier to pass without stimulating bowel contractions.

name: Concerta
description: Colace (docusate) acts as a surfactant in the intestines, reducing the surface tension of stool and allowing water and fats to penetrate and mix with the fecal mass, which increases the water content of the stool, making it softer and easier to pass without stimulating bowel contractions.
mechanism_of_action: Concerta contains methylphenidate, a central nervous system stimulant that works by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain, thereby increasing their concentrations in synaptic clefts; this enhances neurotransmission in brain regions involved in attention and impulse control, resulting in improved focus and behavioral regulation in individuals with ADHD. Concerta uses an advanced OROS (osmotically controlled release oral delivery system) technology, which provides an initial immediate-release dose followed by a gradual, sustained release throughout the day for up to 12 hours of symptom control.

name: Coreg
description: Coreg (carvedilol) is used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), manage symptoms of heart failure, and improve survival and reduce the risk of hospitalization in people with left ventricular dysfunction following a heart attack.
mechanism_of_action: Coreg is a non-selective beta-blocker with alpha-1 blocking activity; it lowers blood pressure and reduces the heart's workload by blocking beta-1 receptors in the heart (slowing heart rate and reducing contractility) and alpha-1 receptors in blood vessels (causing vasodilation), thereby improving heart function and decreasing the risk of cardiovascular events.

name: Coumadin
description: Coumadin (warfarin) is an oral anticoagulant used to treat and prevent blood clots in veins (such as deep vein thrombosis) and arteries (such as pulmonary embolism), and to reduce the risk of stroke, heart attack, or other serious complications in people with conditions like atrial fibrillation, heart valve replacements, or a history of clotting disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Coumadin (warfarin) works by inhibiting the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase in the liver, which is needed to recycle vitamin K. This inhibition reduces the production of active vitamin K–dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) and regulatory proteins C and S, thereby decreasing the blood’s ability to form clots. The result is a prolonged clotting time, which helps prevent harmful clots from forming or growing larger.

name: Crestor
description: Crestor (rosuvastatin) is a statin medication used to lower 'bad' cholesterol (LDL-C), triglycerides, and total cholesterol, while raising 'good' cholesterol (HDL-C) in adults and children (as young as 7 or 8, depending on the condition).
mechanism_of_action: Crestor is a highly selective inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis in the liver. By blocking this enzyme, rosuvastatin reduces the production of cholesterol, which leads to increased expression of LDL receptors on liver cells, enhanced uptake and breakdown of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream, and decreased levels of circulating LDL-C and total cholesterol. It also modestly increases HDL-C and reduces triglycerides.

name: Cymbalta
description: Cymbalta (duloxetine) is a prescription medication used to treat major depressive disorder (MDD) and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) in adults, as well as nerve pain from diabetic neuropathy, fibromyalgia, and chronic musculoskeletal pain in adults. It is also approved for GAD in children ages 7 and older, and fibromyalgia in children ages 13 and older.
mechanism_of_action: Cymbalta is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that works by blocking the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine in the central nervous system, increasing their levels in the synaptic cleft. This modulation of neurotransmitter activity is believed to improve mood and reduce pain perception, although the precise mechanism for each indication is not fully understood.

name: Decadron
description: Decadron (dexamethasone) is a potent corticosteroid used to treat a wide range of inflammatory, autoimmune, allergic, and hormone-related conditions, including severe allergies, asthma, arthritis, skin diseases (such as dermatitis and psoriasis), blood and bone marrow disorders, certain cancers (like leukemia, lymphoma, and multiple myeloma), cerebral edema, gastrointestinal diseases (such as ulcerative colitis), eye and kidney disorders, and for the prevention or treatment of nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy. It is also used in the management of certain nervous system conditions (such as multiple sclerosis exacerbations), and as part of treatment protocols for severely ill COVID-19 patients requiring supplemental oxygen or ventilation.
mechanism_of_action: Decadron (dexamethasone) is a long-acting synthetic glucocorticoid that crosses cell membranes and binds to intracellular glucocorticoid receptors, forming a complex that translocates to the cell nucleus where it alters gene transcription. This leads to suppression of pro-inflammatory mediators (such as cytokines, interleukins, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes), inhibition of immune cell migration and activation (including neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages), stabilization of lysosomal and capillary membranes, and upregulation of anti-inflammatory proteins. The result is a broad anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effect, with negligible mineralocorticoid activity.

name: Depakote
description: Depakote (divalproex sodium) is used to treat certain mood episodes (mania, mixed features) in adults with bipolar disorder, various types of seizures in adults and children (such as complex partial seizures and absence seizures), and prevent migraine headaches in adults.
mechanism_of_action: Depakote’s precise mechanism is not fully understood, but it is believed to work mainly by increasing the levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, which helps calm neural activity and reduce symptoms of mania and seizures. It also blocks voltage-dependent sodium channels, suppressing high-frequency neuronal firing, and may affect multiple molecular pathways involved in neural plasticity and neuroprotection. Additionally, Depakote acts as a histone deacetylase inhibitor, which may influence gene expression and contribute to its therapeutic effects.

name: Dextroamphetamine
description: Dextroamphetamine is a central nervous system stimulant prescribed to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children and adults, as well as narcolepsy, a sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks.
mechanism_of_action: Dextroamphetamine increases the levels of dopamine and norepinephrine (and to a lesser extent, serotonin) in the brain by several mechanisms. It promotes the release of these neurotransmitters from presynaptic nerve terminals, inhibits their reuptake by competitively blocking their transporters (DAT for dopamine, NET for norepinephrine, and SERT for serotonin), inhibits the enzyme monoamine oxidase (MAO), reducing neurotransmitter breakdown, and acts as an agonist at trace amine-associated receptor 1 (TAAR1), which further increases neurotransmitter release and inhibits reuptake.

name: Dextromethorphan
description: Dextromethorphan is an over-the-counter cough suppressant used to reduce the urge to cough caused by the common cold, inhaled irritants, or allergies. It is commonly found in many cough and cold medicines, either alone or in combination with other ingredients, and is used to provide temporary relief from cough that makes it hard to sleep or go about daily activities. Dextromethorphan is also used in combination with other drugs for specific medical conditions, such as pseudobulbar affect (with quinidine) and, in combination with bupropion, for major depressive disorder.
mechanism_of_action: Dextromethorphan works by acting on the brain to suppress the cough reflex. Specifically, it slows activity in certain areas of the brain that trigger coughing. Pharmacologically, it is a noncompetitive NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist and a sigma-1 receptor agonist, and it also acts as a nonselective serotonin reuptake inhibitor at higher doses. These actions elevate the threshold for coughing without affecting ciliary activity in the airways. At standard doses, its primary effect is cough suppression; at higher or non-medical doses, it can produce dissociative and hallucinogenic effects due to NMDA receptor antagonism.

name: Dextrose
description: Dextrose is a simple sugar (chemically identical to glucose) used medically to treat low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), dehydration, and, in some cases, high blood potassium (hyperkalemia). It is commonly administered intravenously in hospitals for rapid correction of hypoglycemia, as a source of calories for patients unable to eat, and sometimes in combination with other drugs or nutrients for nutritional support.
mechanism_of_action: Dextrose is a carbohydrate that is rapidly absorbed and metabolized by the body, providing a quick source of energy for cells and organs. When administered, it raises blood glucose levels, supplying energy to tissues through glycolysis and subsequent metabolic pathways that generate ATP (energy molecules). In the case of hypoglycemia, dextrose quickly restores blood sugar to normal levels. When used for hyperkalemia, dextrose is often given with insulin to help shift potassium from the blood into cells, lowering blood potassium concentrations.

name: Diastat
description: Diastat is a brand name for diazepam rectal gel, which is used as an emergency treatment for acute, intermittent, stereotypic episodes of frequent seizure activity (also known as seizure clusters or acute repetitive seizures) in people with epilepsy. It is intended for use in adults and children ages 2 years and older who are already taking other anti-epileptic medications but need additional control for breakthrough or cluster seizures. Diastat is not meant for daily use, but rather as an as-needed (PRN) rescue medication to stop ongoing seizures and prevent further episodes within a short period.
mechanism_of_action: Diastat (diazepam rectal gel) is a benzodiazepine that enhances the activity of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. By increasing GABA’s effect at the GABAAA receptor, diazepam helps slow down excessive electrical activity in the brain, which is responsible for seizures. This action rapidly calms neuronal firing and can stop ongoing seizures.

name: Diazepam
description: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine used to treat a variety of conditions, including anxiety, acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms (e.g., agitation, tremor, hallucinosis, and delirum tremens), muscle spasms, recurrent seizures, preoperative sedation, etc.
mechanism_of_action: Diazepam acts as a positive allosteric modulator at the GABA-A receptor, the main inhibitory neurotransmitter receptor in the central nervous system. By binding to a specific site on the GABA-A receptor complex, diazepam increases the frequency of chloride channel opening in response to GABA, leading to greater chloride influx, hyperpolarization of neuronal membranes, and reduced neuronal excitability. This produces its characteristic sedative, anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, muscle relaxant, and amnesic effects. The specific clinical effects are mediated by action in different brain regions: anxiolytic effects via the limbic system, muscle relaxant effects via the spinal cord and motor neurons, and sedative/anticonvulsant effects via the cortex, thalamus, and cerebellum.

name: Diclofenac
description: Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat mild to moderate pain and inflammation associated with conditions such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and acute musculoskeletal injuries. It is also used for the treatment of menstrual cramps (dysmenorrhea), acute migraine attacks, postoperative pain, and, in topical forms, for localized relief of pain and swelling from arthritis or minor injuries. Ophthalmic formulations are used for postoperative eye inflammation and pain.
mechanism_of_action: Diclofenac works by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), which are responsible for the synthesis of prostaglandins-substances that mediate inflammation, pain, and fever. By blocking prostaglandin production, diclofenac reduces inflammation, alleviates pain, and lowers fever. It is considered to have partial selectivity for COX-2 over COX-1, which may contribute to its potency and side effect profile. Diclofenac may also inhibit other inflammatory pathways, such as lipoxygenase and phospholipase A2, further reducing the production of pro-inflammatory mediators.

name: Diflucan
description: Diflucan is an antifungal medication used to treat and prevent a wide range of fungal and yeast infections. Common indications include vaginal yeast infections, oral thrust, esophageal candidiasis, systemic candida infections, urinary tract and peritoneal candida infections, cryptococcal meningitis, and prevention of fungal infections in immunocompromised patients.
mechanism_of_action: Fluconazole is an azole antifungal that works by inhibiting the fungal cytochrome P-450 enzyme 14α-demethylase, which is required for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol, a key component of the fungal cell membrane. By blocking ergosterol synthesis, fluconazole disrupts the integrity and function of the fungal cell membrane, leading to impaired cell growth and ultimately cell death.

name: Digoxin
description: Digoxin is primarily used to treat heart failure (especially with reduced ejection fraction) and certain types of abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias), such as chronic atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter. It is often used when other therapies (like beta blockers or calcium channel blockers) are insufficient or not tolerated. Digoxin helps control heart rate in atrial fibrillation and improves symptoms of heart failure, though it does not reduce mortality.
mechanism_of_action: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that works by inhibiting the sodium-potassium ATPase ('sodium pump') in heart muscle cells. This inhibition increases intracellular sodium, which leads to increased intracellular calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. The higher calcium levels enhance the force of heart contractions (positive inotropic effect), improving cardiac output in heart failure. Additionally, digoxin stimulates the vagus nerve (parasympathetic effect), which slows conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node and increases its refractory period. This action helps control heart rate in atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter (negative chronotropic effect.

name: Dilantin
description: Dilantin is an anticonvulsant medication used to control and prevent certain types of seizures, specifically tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizures and focal (partial) seizures in adults and children. It is also used to prevent and treat seizures that may occur during or after neurosurgery. Dilantin is not effective for absence (petit mal) seizures.
mechanism_of_action: Phenytoin works by stabilizing neuronal membranes and decreasing seizure activity in the brain. It does this primarily by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels in their inactive state, which reduces the ability of neurons to fire high-frequency action potentials. This use- and voltage-dependent blockade of sodium channels prevents the spread of seizure activity by filtering out sustained, high-frequency neuronal discharges, while sparing normal brain activity at lower firing rates. The primary site of action is thought to be the motor cortex, where it inhibits the spread of seizure activity.

name: Dilaudid
description: Dilaudid (hydromorphone) is a potent opioid analgesic used to manage moderate to severe pain, particularly when other pain medications have not been effective or cannot be tolerated. It is commonly prescribed for acute pain, severe chronic pain (such as cancer-related pain), and is available in both oral and injectable forms for use in hospital and outpatient settings.
mechanism_of_action: Hydromorphone works by binding to and activating mu-opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord, which blocks the transmission of pain signals and alters the perception of pain. It also has some activity at delta and kappa opioid receptors, but its primary analgesic effect is through the mu-opioid receptor. This activation not only provides pain relief but can also cause sedation, respiratory depression, and euphoria.

name: Diltiazem
description: Diltiazem is a prescription medication used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), chronic stable angina (chest pain), and certain types of abnormal heart rhythms (such as atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter). By lowering blood pressure, it helps reduce the risk of heart attacks, strokes, and other cardiovascular complications. It is also used off-label for conditions like Raynaud's phenomenon and to help heal anal fissures (in topical form).
mechanism_of_action: Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (benzothiazepine class). It works by inhibiting the influx of calcium ions through L-type calcium channels in the heart and vascular smooth muscle during depolarization. This causes relaxation of arterial smooth muscle (vasodilation), lowering peripheral resistance and blood pressure. In the heart, diltiazem slows conduction through the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes, which decreases heart rate (negative chronotropic effect) and reduces the force of contraction (negative inotropic effect). These actions relieve angina by reducing the heart’s oxygen demand and control certain arrhythmias by slowing abnormal electrical conduction.

name: Donepezil
description: Donepezil is primarily used to treat symptoms of dementia associated with Alzheimer’s disease, including memory loss, confusion, and difficulties with thinking and performing daily activities. It is effective in mild, moderate, and severe stages of Alzheimer’s disease, helping to improve or stabilize cognitive function and behavior, though it does not cure the disease or halt its progression.
mechanism_of_action: Donepezil is a selective and reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. It works by blocking the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which breaks down acetylcholine-a neurotransmitter important for memory, learning, and reasoning. By inhibiting this enzyme, donepezil increases the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain, enhancing cholinergic transmission and temporarily improving cognitive symptoms in Alzheimer’s disease.

name: Doxycycline
description: Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat a wide variety of bacterial infections.
mechanism_of_action: Doxycycline is a tetracycline-class antibiotic that works by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit of bacteria, inhibiting protein synthesis. This prevents bacteria from producing essential proteins needed for growth and replication, making doxycycline bacteriostatic (it stops bacteria from multiplying, allowing the immune system to eliminate them). Its high lipophilicity allows it to penetrate tissues effectively, and it is well absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract.

name: Dulcolax
description: Dulcolax is a stimulant laxative used to treat occasional constipation and to empty the bowels before medical procedures such as surgery, colonoscopy, or certain X-rays. It is also used to relieve symptoms of constipation, including abdominal pain, bloating, and hard stool, and can help improve bowel movements in conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
mechanism_of_action: Bisacodyl is a prodrug that is converted in the colon to its active metabolite, bis-(p-hydroxyphenyl)-pyridyl-2-methane (BHPM). This metabolite stimulates parasympathetic nerves in the colon, increasing intestinal motility and secretions, thereby accelerating transit and softening the stool. Bisacodyl also stimulates adenylate cyclase, increasing cyclic AMP, which leads to active secretion of chloride and bicarbonate into the intestinal lumen, with water and electrolytes following passively. Additionally, it decreases the expression of aquaporin 3, reducing water reabsorption from the colon and increasing water content in the stool.

name: DuoNeb
description: DuoNeb is a combination inhalation solution containing albuterol and ipratropium, used to prevent and treat bronchospasm in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. It is typically prescribed for patients who require more than one bronchodilator to control their symptoms and is often used as a 'controller' medication, not for immediate relief during acute flare-ups.
mechanism_of_action: Albuterol is a selective beta-2 adrenergic agonist. It stimulates beta-2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, activating adenyl cyclase and increasing cyclic AMP (cAMP), which relaxes airway muscles and leads to rapid bronchodilation. Ipratropium is an anticholinergic (antimuscarinic) agent. It blocks muscarinic cholinergic receptors in the airways, inhibiting the action of acetylcholine, which decreases cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) and relaxes bronchial smooth muscle, reducing bronchoconstriction and airway secretions.

name: Effexor
description: Effexor is an antidepressant used to treat several mental health conditions in adults, including nmajor despressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), social anxiety disorder (SAD), and panic disorder.
mechanism_of_action: Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). At lower doses, it primarily inhibits the reuptake of serotonin, acting similarly to an SSRI; at higher doses, it also inhibits norepinephrine reuptake, and to a lesser extent, dopamine reuptake. By blocking these neurotransmitter transporters, venlafaxine increases the levels of serotonin and norepinephrine (and, weakly, dopamine) in the brain, which helps improve mood, reduce anxiety, and relieve pain symptoms.

name: Entresto
description: Entresto is a prescription medication used to treat chronic heart failure, particularly in adults with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), meaning the heart’s left side pumps out less blood than normal. It is FDA-approved to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization due to heart failure. Entresto is also approved for use in children ages 1 year and older with symptomatic heart failure due to systemic left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
mechanism_of_action: Entresto is the first-in-class angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI). It contains two active components. Sacubitril: a neprilysin inhibitor that increases levels of beneficial peptides (natriuretic peptides) by preventing their breakdown. This action helps dilate blood vessels, reduce sodium retention, and decrease fluid buildup. Valsartan: an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) that blocks the effects of angiotensin II at the AT1 receptor, leading to vasodilation, reduced aldosterone secretion, and lower blood pressure.

name: Epinephrine
description: Epinephrine is a life-saving medication primarily used to treat severe allergic reactions (anaphylaxis), including those caused by foods, insect stings, medications, and other allergens. It is also used in emergency medicine to restore cardiac rhythm during cardiac arrest, manage severe asthma attacks, treat croup, control mucosal congestion, and as an adjunct to local anesthetics to prolong their effect and reduce bleeding.
mechanism_of_action: Epinephrine is a nonselective agonist of all alpha (α1, α2) and beta (β1, β2, β3) adrenergic receptors. Alpha-adrenergic effects: Causes vasoconstriction, which raises blood pressure and reduces swelling and fluid leakage during anaphylaxis. Beta-1 adrenergic effects: Increases heart rate, contractility, and cardiac output, helping to restore heart function in cardiac arrest and support blood pressure. eta-2 adrenergic effects: Relaxes bronchial smooth muscle, leading to bronchodilation and rapid relief of airway constriction in asthma or anaphylaxis.

name: Erythromycin
description: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections, whooping cough (pertussis), diphtheria, skin and soft tissue infections, ear infections, intestinal infections, seuxally transmitted infections, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
mechanism_of_action: Erythromycin works by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, inhibiting protein synthesis by blocking the translocation step and preventing the growth and multiplication of bacteria. This action is primarily bacteriostatic (stops bacterial growth), but can be bactericidal (kills bacteria) at higher concentrations. Erythromycin also acts as a motilin receptor agonist, which can increase gut motility.

name: Excedrin
description: Excedrin is an over-the-counter combination medication used to provide temporary relief from headaches (including migraines and tension headaches), as well as minor aches and pains due to conditions such as arthritis, muscle aches, toothaches, menstrual cramps, colds, and premenstrual pain.
mechanism_of_action: Excedrin contains three active ingredients that work together to relieve pain. Acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic that acts primarily in the central nervous system to raise the pain threshold, likely by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis in the brain. Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that reduces pain, inflammation, and fever by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins through irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes. Caffeine is a central nervous system stimulant and vasoconstrictor. It enhances the pain-relieving effects of acetaminophen and aspirin, and by constricting blood vessels, it can help counteract the vasodilation thought to contribute to headache and migraine symptoms.

name: Famotidine
description: Famotidine is used to treat and prevent conditions caused by excess stomach acid, including heartburn and acid indigestion, stomach and small intestine (duodenal) ulcers, GERD, erosive esophagitis caused by acid reflux, and pathological hypersecretory conditions such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
mechanism_of_action: Famotidine is a histamine H2 receptor antagonist (H2 blocker). It works by competitively blocking H2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of gastric parietal cells, which inhibits the action of histamine and reduces both the volume and acidity of gastric secretions. This results in decreased stomach acid production, providing relief from acid-related symptoms and promoting ulcer healing.

name: Farxiga
description: Farxiga is a prescription medication used to improve blood sugar control in adults and children (age 10 and older) with type 2 diabetes, alongside diet and exercise, reduce the risk of hospitalization for heart failure in adults with type 2 diabetes who also have cardiovascular disease or multiple risk factors, lower the risk of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for heart failure, and urgent heart failure visits in adults with heart failure, and reduce the risk of worsening kidney disease, end-stage kidney disease, cardiovascular death, and hospitalization for heart failure in adults with chronic kidney disease at risk of progression
mechanism_of_action: Farxiga is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. It works by inhibiting SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules of the kidneys, which reduces the reabsorption of filtered glucose and sodium, reducing sodium reabsorption, which leads to osmotic diuresis and natriuresis (loss of water and sodium), lowering blood pressure and reducing fluid overload-key benefits in heart failure and chronic kidney disease, reducing intraglomerular pressure in the kidneys, which helps protect against further kidney damage, and lowering the activity of the sympathetic nervous system and reducing cardiac preload and afterload, thereby decreasing strain on the heart and improving heart function in heart failure.

name: Fenofibrate
description: Fenofibrate is a medication primarily used to lower elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels in adults, particularly in cases of mixed dyslipidemia (high LDL and triglycerides with low HDL), severe hypertriglyceridemia, and primary hypercholesterolemia. It is often prescribed alongside a low-fat diet and exercise, and may be used in combination with other lipid-lowering medications if lifestyle changes alone are insufficient. By improving lipid profiles, fenofibrate aims to reduce the risk of complications such as pancreatitis and, in certain populations, may help lower cardiovascular risk, especially in those with high triglycerides and low HDL cholesterol.
mechanism_of_action: Fenofibrate involves activation of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα), a nuclear receptor that regulates lipid metabolism. Activation of PPARα increases the expression of lipoprotein lipase and reduces apoprotein CIII, thereby enhancing the breakdown and clearance of triglyceride-rich particles from the blood. It also increases the synthesis of apoproteins AI and AII, leading to higher HDL (good) cholesterol levels, and reduces the production of very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and LDL (bad) cholesterol. Through these effects, fenofibrate lowers plasma triglycerides, VLDL, and LDL cholesterol, while raising HDL cholesterol, thus improving overall lipid balance.

name: Fentanyl
description: Fentanyl is a highly potent synthetic opioid used medically for the management of severe pain, such as pain following surgery or pain in patients with advanced cancer who are tolerant to other opioids. It is approximately 50 to 100 times more potent than morphine and is typically prescribed in forms such as injections, transdermal patches, and lozenges. Fentanyl is also sometimes used as an anesthetic adjunct in hospital settings.
mechanism_of_action: The mechanism of action of fentanyl involves binding primarily to mu-opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord. This activation blocks pain pathways, leading to profound analgesia, sedation, and feelings of euphoria. Fentanyl also increases dopamine release in reward areas of the brain, which contributes to its addictive potential. It can activate other opioid receptors, such as delta and kappa, but its primary effects are mediated through mu-receptor agonism.

name: Flagyl
description: Flagyl is the brand name for metronidazole, an antibiotic and antiprotozoal medication used to treat a wide range of infections. It is commonly prescribed for bacterial infections of the vagina (such as bacterial vaginosis), stomach, intestines, liver, skin, joints, brain and spinal cord, lungs, heart, and bloodstream. Flagyl is also used to treat certain parasitic infections, including trichomoniasis (a sexually transmitted infection), amebiasis, and giardiasis. Additionally, it is used to prevent infections after certain surgical procedures, especially those involving the colon or abdomen.
mechanism_of_action: Flagyl works by entering bacterial and protozoal cells and, under low-oxygen (anaerobic) conditions, is reduced to its active form. This active form interacts with microbial DNA, causing DNA strand breaks and inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis, ultimately leading to cell death. Its mechanism is highly effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa, but it does not affect viruses or aerobic bacteria.

name: Flecainide
description: Flecainide is a prescription antiarrhythmic medication used to treat certain serious and potentially life-threatening abnormal heart rhythms. It is most commonly prescribed for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), paroxysmal atrial fibrillation or flutter, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, and other supraventricular tachycardias, especially in patients without significant structural heart disease. Flecainide may also be used to manage sustained ventricular tachycardia and has a role in treating arrhythmias such as catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT) and fetal tachycardia.
mechanism_of_action: Flecainide is classified as a class Ic antiarrhythmic agent. Its primary mechanism of action is the potent blockade of fast inward sodium (Na+) channels in cardiac cells, which slows the upstroke of the cardiac action potential and reduces excitability, especially in the His-Purkinje system and ventricular myocardium. This results in slowed conduction of electrical impulses through the heart and stabilization of the heartbeat. Flecainide also inhibits the delayed rectifier potassium current (IKr), prolonging the action potential duration, and blocks ryanodine receptor 2 (RyR2), reducing abnormal calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which helps suppress arrhythmogenic triggers, particularly in CPVT. The drug’s sodium channel blockade is use-dependent, meaning its effect increases with faster heart rates, making it especially effective in treating tachyarrhythmias.

name: Flexeril
description: Flexeril (cyclobenzaprine), is a skeletal muscle relaxant used alongside rest and physical therapy to relieve muscle spasms and discomfort associated with acute, painful musculoskeletal conditions such as strains, sprains, or other muscle injuries. It is not effective for muscle spasms caused by central nervous system diseases like cerebral palsy.
mechanism_of_action: Cyclobenzaprine works primarily by acting on the central nervous system, specifically at the brainstem level, to reduce tonic somatic motor activity. It decreases muscle hyperactivity by influencing both gamma and alpha motor systems, thereby blocking nerve impulses or pain sensations sent to the brain. This mechanism helps relieve muscle spasms without directly affecting muscle function or causing muscle weakness.

name: Flomax
description: Flomax (tamsulosin) a prescription medication primarily used to treat symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is an enlarged, non-cancerous prostate gland common in older men. BPH can cause urinary symptoms such as frequent or urgent need to urinate, difficulty starting urination, weak or intermittent urine stream, dribbling at the end of urination, and a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying. Flomax helps relieve these symptoms by relaxing the muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, making it easier to urinate.
mechanism_of_action: The mechanism of action of tamsulosin involves selective blockade of alpha-1A adrenergic receptors, which are predominantly found in the smooth muscle of the prostate, bladder neck, and urethra. By blocking these receptors, tamsulosin causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in these areas, reducing resistance to urinary flow and improving BPH symptoms. Its selectivity for alpha-1A over alpha-1B receptors (which are more common in blood vessels) means it is less likely to cause significant drops in blood pressure compared to less selective alpha blockers.

name: Flonase
description: Used to relieve symptoms of seasonal and year-round allergic and non-allergic rhinitis, such as sneezing, runny or stuffy nose, nasal itching, and itchy or watery eyes. It is also used to treat chronic rhinosinusitis with or without nasal polyps.
mechanism_of_action: Reduces inflammation in the nasal passages by blocking the release of multiple inflammatory substances, including histamine and cytokines, resulting in relief of allergy and nasal symptoms.

name: Fluconazole
description: Treats and prevents a wide range of fungal and yeast infections, including vaginal yeast infections, oral and esophageal thrush, systemic and urinary tract Candida infections, cryptococcal meningitis, and fungal infections in immunocompromised patients (such as those with HIV, cancer, or post-transplant).
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits the fungal enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, blocking the synthesis of ergosterol, an essential component of the fungal cell membrane, resulting in impaired cell membrane formation and inhibition of fungal growth.

name: Fluoxetine
description: Treats major depressive disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), panic disorder, bulimia nervosa, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Also used in combination with olanzapine for treatment-resistant depression and depressive episodes in bipolar I disorder.
mechanism_of_action: Increases serotonin levels in the brain by selectively inhibiting its reuptake into nerve cells, which helps improve mood, reduce anxiety, and control compulsive behaviors.

name: Fosamax
description: Treats and prevents osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and men, including osteoporosis caused by long-term use of glucocorticoids. Also used to treat Paget’s disease of bone, a condition that leads to abnormal bone destruction and regrowth, resulting in bone deformity and pain.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bone breakdown by blocking osteoclast activity through interference with the mevalonate pathway, leading to decreased bone resorption and increased bone density.

name: Furosemide
description: Treats fluid retention (edema) caused by conditions such as congestive heart failure, liver disease, and kidney disease, including nephrotic syndrome. Also used alone or with other medications to manage high blood pressure (hypertension).
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the kidneys, specifically at the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which increases urine production and removes excess fluid and salt from the body.

name: Gabapentin
description: Used to manage nerve pain from shingles (postherpetic neuralgia), control partial seizures in epilepsy (often as an add-on therapy), and treat moderate-to-severe restless legs syndrome. Frequently prescribed off-label for neuropathic pain from other causes, fibromyalgia, hot flashes, and certain mood or anxiety disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels in the nervous system, reducing the release of excitatory neurotransmitters and decreasing abnormal nerve activity that causes seizures and neuropathic pain.

name: Galantamine
description: Used to treat mild to moderate dementia associated with Alzheimer’s disease. It can help improve memory, awareness, and the ability to perform daily functions in affected individuals. Off-label, it may be used for other types of dementia and certain neurological or psychiatric conditions, but its primary indication is Alzheimer’s-related cognitive impairment.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits acetylcholinesterase to increase acetylcholine levels in the brain and also acts as a positive allosteric modulator at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, enhancing cholinergic neurotransmission and supporting cognitive function.

name: Glipizde
description: Used to lower blood sugar levels in people with type 2 diabetes, typically alongside diet and exercise, and sometimes with other diabetes medications.
mechanism_of_action: Stimulates the pancreas to release more insulin by blocking ATP-sensitive potassium channels on pancreatic beta cells, causing cell depolarization and calcium influx, which triggers insulin secretion.

name: Glucagon
description: Treats severe hypoglycemia (very low blood sugar), especially in people with diabetes who cannot safely take oral glucose. Also used as a diagnostic aid during gastrointestinal imaging to relax the GI tract, and off-label for beta-blocker or calcium channel blocker overdose and esophageal food impaction.
mechanism_of_action: Stimulates the liver to rapidly release glucose into the bloodstream by activating glucagon receptors, which trigger glycogen breakdown (glycogenolysis) and new glucose production (gluconeogenesis), raising blood sugar levels. Also relaxes smooth muscle in the gastrointestinal tract.

name: Glucophage
description: Used to manage and lower blood sugar levels in people with type 2 diabetes, especially when diet and exercise alone are not sufficient. It can be used alone or in combination with other diabetes medications, including insulin, to help prevent complications associated with high blood sugar.
mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood sugar primarily by decreasing glucose production in the liver (inhibiting hepatic gluconeogenesis), increasing insulin sensitivity in muscle and fat, and reducing intestinal absorption of glucose.

name: Glucosamine
description: Commonly used to relieve symptoms of osteoarthritis, especially in the knee, by supporting joint health and reducing pain and stiffness. Sometimes used for other joint-related conditions, but strong evidence primarily supports its use in osteoarthritis.
mechanism_of_action: Serves as a building block for glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans, which are essential for cartilage structure. May stimulate cartilage production and slow its breakdown, helping maintain joint function and reduce inflammation in osteoarthritis.

name: Guaifenesin
description: Used to relieve chest congestion and help clear mucus from the airways in conditions such as the common cold, flu, bronchitis, and other respiratory illnesses that cause productive cough.
mechanism_of_action: Thins and loosens mucus in the airways by increasing the volume and decreasing the viscosity of bronchial secretions, making coughs more productive and helping clear mucus from the respiratory tract.

name: Halicon
description: Used for the short-term treatment of insomnia, particularly to help with trouble falling or staying asleep. Typically prescribed for 7 to 10 days in adults when sleep disturbances are severe and disabling.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA at benzodiazepine receptors in the brain, producing sedative, hypnotic, and anxiolytic effects that promote sleep.

name: Haldol
description: Used to treat schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, control tics and vocal outbursts in Tourette syndrome, and manage severe behavioral problems in children when other treatments have failed. Also prescribed for acute agitation, delirium, and sometimes for severe nausea or vomiting in palliative care.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, reducing the effects of dopamine and helping to control symptoms of psychosis, agitation, and tics.

name: Haloperidol
description: Used to treat schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, control tics and vocal outbursts in Tourette syndrome, manage severe behavioral problems in children when other treatments have failed, and address acute agitation, delirium, and severe confusion or aggression in various medical and psychiatric settings. Also used for the treatment of mania in bipolar disorder and as an antiemetic in palliative care for severe nausea and vomiting.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, reducing dopamine activity, which helps control symptoms of psychosis, agitation, and tics.

name: Heparin
description: Used to prevent and treat blood clots in conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), atrial fibrillation, acute coronary syndromes, and during surgeries or procedures that increase clot risk (like cardiac surgery, dialysis, or blood transfusions). Also used to maintain patency of intravenous catheters and for other thrombotic or embolic disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the activity of antithrombin III, which rapidly inactivates clotting factors-especially thrombin (factor IIa) and factor Xa-thereby preventing the formation and extension of blood clots.

name: Humalog
description: Used to control high blood sugar in adults and children with type 1 or type 2 diabetes. Helps manage blood glucose levels around mealtimes to prevent complications from diabetes, such as nerve damage, kidney problems, and vision loss.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a rapid-acting insulin analog that lowers blood sugar by promoting glucose uptake into muscle and fat cells and reducing glucose production by the liver. Starts working within about 15 minutes of injection, peaks at around 1 hour, and lasts 2 to 4 hours.

name: Humira
description: Treats a variety of autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, plaque psoriasis, hidradenitis suppurativa, and certain types of uveitis. Used in both adults and children, depending on the specific condition and age.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to and neutralizes tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), a key inflammatory protein, blocking its interaction with cell surface receptors and thereby reducing inflammation and immune-mediated tissue damage.

name: Hydralazine
description: Treats high blood pressure (hypertension), including severe or resistant cases, and is also used in managing heart failure (especially in combination with isosorbide dinitrate), hypertensive emergencies, and acute hypertension in pregnancy (such as preeclampsia or eclampsia).
mechanism_of_action: Directly relaxes arterial smooth muscle, leading to vasodilation and reduced blood pressure. This effect is thought to involve inhibition of calcium release within vascular smooth muscle cells, which decreases peripheral resistance and lowers blood pressure.

name: Hydrea
description: Used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), certain cancers of the head and neck (including locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma), and to reduce the frequency of painful crises and the need for blood transfusions in sickle cell anemia. Also prescribed for polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia, and sometimes for other blood disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase, blocking DNA synthesis and slowing or stopping the growth of rapidly dividing cells. In sickle cell anemia, increases fetal hemoglobin production, which helps prevent sickling of red blood cells.

name: Hydrochlorothiazide
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and manage edema (fluid retention) caused by conditions such as heart failure, kidney disease, or liver disease. Also prescribed for prevention of kidney stones in people with high calcium in their urine, and for certain cases of diabetes insipidus and other rare disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, increasing urine output and reducing fluid in the body, which lowers blood pressure and decreases swelling.

name: Hydrocodone
description: Used to manage severe pain that requires around-the-clock opioid treatment and cannot be controlled with other pain medications. Also prescribed in combination products to relieve moderate to severe pain or to suppress cough in adults when other treatments are inadequate.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to and activates mu-opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord, blocking pain signal transmission and altering the perception of pain. Also suppresses the cough reflex by acting on the cough center in the medulla.

name: Hydrocortisone
description: Used to treat a wide range of conditions, including inflammation and allergic reactions affecting the skin (eczema, dermatitis, psoriasis, insect bites), joints (arthritis, bursitis), and internal organs (asthma, lupus, ulcerative colitis). Also prescribed as hormone replacement therapy for adrenal insufficiency (such as Addison’s disease) and for severe allergic reactions, certain cancers, and immune-related disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to glucocorticoid receptors, altering gene expression to suppress the immune response and reduce production of inflammatory chemicals, leading to decreased swelling, redness, itching, and pain. Also replaces deficient cortisol in adrenal insufficiency.

name: Hydroxychloroquine
description: Used to prevent and treat malaria, as well as to manage autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), discoid lupus, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Also prescribed for certain skin conditions and off-label for other connective tissue diseases.
mechanism_of_action: Modulates immune system activity by increasing the pH within lysosomes and endosomes of immune cells, which interferes with antigen processing and presentation. Also inhibits activation of toll-like receptors, reducing the production of inflammatory cytokines. In malaria, kills the parasite by disrupting its ability to digest hemoglobin.

name: Hydroxyurea
description: Used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), certain cancers of the head and neck, and to reduce the frequency of painful crises and the need for blood transfusions in sickle cell anemia. Also prescribed for polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and other myeloproliferative disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks DNA synthesis by inhibiting the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase, which slows or stops the growth of rapidly dividing cells in cancer. In sickle cell anemia, increases fetal hemoglobin (HbF) production, making red blood cells less likely to sickle and reducing painful episodes.

name: Hydroxyzine
description: Used to relieve itching from allergic skin reactions, manage anxiety and tension, provide sedation before and after general anesthesia, and treat nausea and vomiting. Also prescribed for short-term management of insomnia and as an adjunct in certain psychiatric and medical conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a potent inverse agonist at histamine H1 receptors, blocking the effects of histamine to reduce allergy symptoms and itching. Also produces sedative and anxiolytic effects by decreasing activity in the brain, which helps with anxiety and promotes relaxation.

name: Ibuprofen
description: Used to reduce fever and relieve mild to moderate pain and inflammation from conditions such as headache, toothache, back pain, menstrual cramps, muscle aches, arthritis (osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis), and minor injuries. Also used for symptomatic relief of cold and flu and to manage pain after surgery or dental procedures.
mechanism_of_action: Nonselectively inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) enzymes, reducing the production of prostaglandins that cause pain, inflammation, and fever.

name: Imbruvica
description: Treats chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL), Waldenström’s macroglobulinemia (WM), and chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) in adults and children aged 1 year and older who have not responded to other treatments.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK), a key enzyme in B-cell signaling pathways, by forming a covalent bond with the enzyme. This inhibition disrupts cancer cell growth and survival in B-cell malignancies and reduces abnormal immune cell activity in cGVHD.

name: Imiquimod
description: Used to treat actinic keratosis (precancerous skin growths), superficial basal cell carcinoma (a type of skin cancer), and external genital and perianal warts. It may also be prescribed for other abnormal skin growths and certain off-label uses, such as vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia or resistant herpes simplex lesions.
mechanism_of_action: Activates the immune system by stimulating toll-like receptor 7 (TLR7) on immune cells, leading to the release of cytokines such as interferon-alpha, interleukin-6, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha. This immune activation helps the body target and clear abnormal skin cells, warts, and some skin cancers.

name: Imitrex
description: Used to treat acute migraine attacks in adults, with or without aura, and to relieve associated symptoms such as headache pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light or sound. The injectable form is also used for acute cluster headaches. It does not prevent migraines or cluster headaches, but treats symptoms once they begin.
mechanism_of_action: Activates serotonin 5-HT1B and 5-HT1D receptors, causing constriction of cranial blood vessels and reducing the release of inflammatory neuropeptides, which relieves migraine and cluster headache symptoms.

name: Imodium
description: Used to relieve acute diarrhea and reduce the frequency and urgency of bowel movements. Also helps control chronic diarrhea in conditions like inflammatory bowel disease and can decrease stool output in people with an ileostomy. Provides symptomatic relief from associated symptoms such as gas, bloating, and cramps.
mechanism_of_action: Slows intestinal movement by activating opioid receptors in the gut wall, which decreases peristalsis and increases absorption of fluids and electrolytes, resulting in firmer stools and fewer bowel movements.

name: Ivermectin
description: Used to treat a variety of parasitic infections, including onchocerciasis (river blindness), strongyloidiasis (intestinal threadworm), scabies, head lice, and other worm infections such as ascariasis, trichuriasis, filariasis, and cutaneous larva migrans. Topical forms are also used for rosacea associated with Demodex mite infestation.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to glutamate-gated chloride channels in nerve and muscle cells of parasites, increasing chloride ion influx, which leads to paralysis and death of the parasite. This action is highly selective for invertebrates and does not affect mammalian cells at standard doses.

name: Janumet
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes when diet and exercise alone are not enough. Not used for type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis.
mechanism_of_action: Combines two medicines: sitagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin hormones to boost insulin release and lower glucagon after meals, and metformin, a biguanide that decreases liver glucose production, reduces intestinal glucose absorption, and improves insulin sensitivity in the body.

name: Jakafi
description: Used to treat adults with myelofibrosis (a type of bone marrow cancer), adults with polycythemia vera who did not respond to or could not tolerate hydroxyurea, and adults and children 12 years and older with acute or chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) after failure of prior treatments.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the activity of Janus kinase 1 and 2 (JAK1 and JAK2), enzymes that are overactive in certain blood disorders and GVHD, thereby reducing abnormal blood cell production and dampening harmful immune signaling.

name: Januvia
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes, alongside diet and exercise. Not used for type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis, and typically prescribed alone or with other diabetes medications if needed.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the enzyme DPP-4, which increases levels of incretin hormones. This boosts insulin release from the pancreas and lowers glucagon levels after meals, helping to reduce blood sugar.

name: Jardiance
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults and children with type 2 diabetes, reduce the risk of cardiovascular death in people with type 2 diabetes and established heart disease, lower the risk of hospitalization and death in adults with heart failure, and decrease the risk of disease progression and serious complications in adults with chronic kidney disease.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the SGLT2 protein in the kidneys, reducing reabsorption of glucose back into the blood and increasing its excretion in urine, which lowers blood sugar. Also reduces sodium reabsorption, helping lower blood pressure and decrease strain on the heart and kidneys.

name: Kariva
description: Used to prevent pregnancy as an oral contraceptive. Also sometimes prescribed off-label to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce menstrual pain, and manage acne or other hormone-related conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Prevents ovulation and thickens cervical mucus to block sperm entry, while altering the uterine lining to reduce the likelihood of implantation. The combined effect of estrogen and progestin hormones makes pregnancy much less likely.

name: Kayexalate
description: Used to treat high potassium levels in the blood (hyperkalemia), typically in people with kidney problems or other conditions that cause dangerous elevations in potassium. It is not intended for emergency treatment of life-threatening hyperkalemia due to its delayed onset of action.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a non-absorbed cation exchange resin in the gastrointestinal tract, where it exchanges sodium ions for potassium ions, binding potassium in the gut and increasing its excretion in the stool, thereby lowering serum potassium levels.

name: Keflex
description: Treats a variety of bacterial infections, including upper and lower respiratory tract infections, ear infections (otitis media), skin and soft tissue infections, urinary tract infections (UTIs), bone infections, and acute prostatitis. Effective against susceptible strains of bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins, leading to cell lysis and death in susceptible bacteria (bactericidal effect).

name: Kenalog
description: Treats a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, including joint disorders (such as rheumatoid arthritis, gout, and bursitis), skin diseases (like eczema, psoriasis, discoid lupus, and lichen planus), severe allergic reactions, ulcerative colitis, and inflammatory eye, lung, blood, and endocrine disorders. It is used as an injection into joints, muscles, skin lesions, or as a topical or nasal preparation, depending on the condition.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a potent corticosteroid by binding to glucocorticoid receptors, suppressing the immune response and reducing the production of inflammatory chemicals, which decreases swelling, redness, itching, and pain in affected tissues.

name: Keppra
description: Used to treat various types of seizures in epilepsy, including focal (partial-onset) seizures in adults and children (ages 1 month and older), myoclonic seizures in people with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (ages 12 and older), and generalized tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizures in adults and children (ages 6 and older). Often prescribed alone or in combination with other antiepileptic drugs.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A) in the brain, modulating neurotransmitter release and reducing abnormal electrical activity that causes seizures.

name: Ketamine
description: Used as a general anesthetic for surgical and diagnostic procedures, procedural sedation, and pain management (especially for severe or refractory pain). Also used off-label for treatment-resistant depression, certain anxiety disorders, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and refractory status epilepticus. In emergency and critical care, it is valued for rapid sedation, short-term anesthesia, and as an adjunct in pain control.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors in the brain, reducing excitatory neurotransmission and producing dissociative anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation. Also increases glutamate release and stimulates AMPA receptors, which may enhance neuroplasticity and underlie its rapid antidepressant effects. Additional actions include mild activity at opioid, monoaminergic, and cholinergic receptors.

name: Ketorolac
description: Used for short-term management of moderate to severe acute pain, often after surgery or injury, when pain requires strong relief. Also prescribed for pain relief in conditions such as musculoskeletal pain, migraines, dental pain, and pain during menstruation. Not intended for long-term use due to risk of serious side effects.
mechanism_of_action: Nonselectively blocks cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing production of prostaglandins-chemicals in the body that cause pain, inflammation, and fever.

name: Keytruda
description: Treats a wide range of cancers, including melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, classical Hodgkin lymphoma, urothelial carcinoma, gastric cancer, esophageal cancer, cervical cancer, endometrial cancer, renal cell carcinoma, triple-negative breast cancer, malignant pleural mesothelioma, biliary tract cancer, colorectal cancer with certain genetic features, and several other solid tumors. Used in adults and some children, often for advanced, metastatic, or treatment-resistant cancers.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the PD-1 receptor on T cells, preventing its interaction with PD-L1 and PD-L2 proteins on tumor cells. This restores the immune system’s ability to recognize and attack cancer cells by reactivating T cell responses that tumors may have suppressed.

name: Klonopin
description: Used to treat certain types of seizure disorders (including absence seizures, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, myoclonic and akinetic seizures), panic disorder with or without agoraphobia, and as a short-term therapy for acute management of epilepsy. Also prescribed off-label for anxiety disorders, REM sleep behavior disorder, restless legs syndrome, and some movement and sleep disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA by binding to benzodiazepine receptors in the brain, producing a calming effect that reduces abnormal electrical activity, prevents seizures, and decreases anxiety.

name: Klor-Con
description: Used to prevent or treat low blood potassium levels (hypokalemia), which can result from certain diseases, medications (such as diuretics), or prolonged illness with vomiting or diarrhea. Also indicated for patients at risk of developing hypokalemia, especially those with cardiac arrhythmias or on digitalis therapy, when dietary management or dose reduction of diuretics is insufficient.
mechanism_of_action: Replenishes potassium by providing potassium ions, which are essential for nerve impulse transmission, muscle contraction (including the heart), and maintaining normal cellular function. Potassium is the main intracellular cation, and supplementation restores normal physiologic balance when levels are low.

name: Labetalol
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), including severe hypertension and hypertension during pregnancy. Also prescribed for hypertensive emergencies and sometimes for angina or to help prevent complications from high blood pressure, such as heart attack and stroke.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks both beta-adrenergic (β1 and β2) and alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, leading to slowed heart rate, reduced force of heart contractions, and relaxation of blood vessels. This dual action lowers blood pressure by decreasing resistance in the blood vessels and reducing the heart’s workload.

name: Lacosamide
description: Used to treat partial-onset (focal) seizures in adults and children, and as adjunct therapy for primary generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Sometimes prescribed off-label for neuropathic pain and other neurological conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels in neurons, stabilizing hyperexcitable nerve membranes and reducing repetitive firing that leads to seizures. Also modulates collapsin response mediator protein-2 (CRMP-2), which may help prevent abnormal neuronal connections.

name: Lactulose
description: Used to treat chronic constipation and to prevent and manage hepatic encephalopathy, a brain disorder caused by liver disease that leads to elevated blood ammonia levels. Also sometimes used for other conditions such as small intestine bacterial overgrowth testing and to counteract constipation from opioid use or hemorrhoids.
mechanism_of_action: For constipation, acts as an osmotic laxative by drawing water into the colon, softening stool, and increasing bowel movements. For hepatic encephalopathy, is broken down by gut bacteria into acids that acidify the colon, converting ammonia into non-absorbable ammonium ions and promoting its excretion, thereby lowering blood ammonia levels.

name: Lamictal
description: Used to treat various types of epileptic seizures in adults and children, including partial seizures, primary generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Also prescribed as a maintenance treatment to delay mood episodes in adults with bipolar I disorder, helping to prevent both depressive and manic episodes.
mechanism_of_action: Stabilizes brain activity by blocking voltage-sensitive sodium channels, which reduces the release of excitatory neurotransmitters like glutamate and aspartate. This action helps control seizures and mood swings in bipolar disorder.

name: Lantus
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes and in children aged 6 years and older with type 1 diabetes. Not used for diabetic ketoacidosis. Administered once daily by subcutaneous injection as part of a diabetes management plan that includes diet and exercise.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a long-acting insulin analog that lowers blood glucose by stimulating uptake of glucose into muscle and fat cells and inhibiting glucose production by the liver. Provides a steady, 24-hour glucose-lowering effect with no pronounced peak.

name: Lasix
description: Used to treat fluid retention (edema) caused by conditions such as congestive heart failure, liver disease, and kidney disorders (including nephrotic syndrome). Also prescribed to manage high blood pressure (hypertension).
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney, leading to increased urine output and removal of excess fluid and salt from the body.

name: Levalbuterol
description: Used to prevent and relieve wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness in conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Acts as a quick-relief (rescue) medication for acute bronchospasm and is suitable for both adults and children.
mechanism_of_action: Relaxes airway smooth muscle by selectively stimulating beta-2 adrenergic receptors, increasing cyclic AMP and leading to bronchodilation. This opens the airways quickly, making it easier to breathe during asthma attacks or episodes of bronchospasm.

name: Levaquin
description: Treats a wide range of serious bacterial infections, including pneumonia (community-acquired and hospital-acquired), skin and soft tissue infections, urinary tract infections (including acute pyelonephritis), chronic bacterial prostatitis, acute bacterial sinusitis, and acute bacterial exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. Also used to prevent or treat inhalational anthrax and plague, and for certain off-label uses such as endocarditis, some sexually transmitted diseases, and traveler's diarrhea.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, enzymes essential for DNA replication, transcription, repair, and recombination, leading to bacterial cell death.

name: Levodopa
description: Treats Parkinson’s disease and related movement disorders (such as parkinsonism from other causes and dopamine-responsive dystonia) by improving motor symptoms like rigidity, bradykinesia (slowness), and tremor. Also used for parkinsonism caused by encephalitis or toxins (e.g., carbon monoxide, manganese).
mechanism_of_action: Crosses the blood-brain barrier and is converted to dopamine in the brain, supplementing low dopamine levels and stimulating dopamine receptors to improve movement. Usually given with a peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitor (such as carbidopa or benserazide) to prevent conversion to dopamine outside the brain, which enhances effectiveness and reduces side effects.

name: Levothyroxine
description: Used to treat hypothyroidism (an underactive thyroid), where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone. Also prescribed to help decrease the size of enlarged thyroid glands (goiter), and as part of treatment for certain types of thyroid cancer, usually in combination with surgery and radioactive iodine therapy.
mechanism_of_action: Provides a synthetic form of thyroxine (T4), the main hormone produced by the thyroid gland. In the body, T4 is converted to the active hormone triiodothyronine (T3), which enters cell nuclei and regulates gene expression to control metabolism, growth, and development. Levothyroxine restores normal thyroid hormone levels, reversing symptoms of hypothyroidism.

name: Lexapro
description: Used to treat major depressive disorder and generalized anxiety disorder in adults and children (depression in those 12 years and older, anxiety in those 7 years and older). Also sometimes prescribed off-label for other anxiety-related conditions as determined by a healthcare provider.
mechanism_of_action: Increases serotonin levels in the brain by selectively blocking its reuptake into nerve cells, which helps regulate mood and reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety.

name: Lidocaine
description: Used to provide local anesthesia (numbing) for minor surgical or dental procedures, to relieve pain from conditions like minor burns, scrapes, insect bites, and nerve pain (such as postherpetic neuralgia), and to treat certain abnormal heart rhythms (ventricular arrhythmias). Also used as a topical pain reliever for targeted pain relief in muscles and joints, and for procedures involving mucous membranes.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels in nerve cell membranes, preventing the initiation and conduction of nerve impulses. This numbs the area by stopping nerves from sending pain signals to the brain. When used intravenously for heart rhythm problems, it slows electrical conduction in the heart by the same sodium channel blockade, helping to control abnormal heartbeats.

name: Lipitor
description: Used to lower high cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the blood, reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke, and decrease the need for heart surgery in people with or at risk for heart disease. Also prescribed to treat inherited forms of high cholesterol (such as familial hypercholesterolemia) in adults and children, typically alongside diet and lifestyle changes.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase in the liver, reducing cholesterol production. This lowers LDL ('bad') cholesterol and triglycerides, raises HDL ('good') cholesterol, and helps prevent cholesterol buildup in blood vessels.

name: Lisdexamfetamine
description: Lisdexamfetamine is a prescription central nervous system (CNS) stimulant used primarily to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in adults and children aged 6 years and older, as well as moderate to severe binge eating disorder (BED) in adults. It is usually part of a broader treatment plan that may also include behavioral, educational, and psychological interventions.
mechanism_of_action: Converted in the body to dextroamphetamine, which increases dopamine and norepinephrine levels in the brain to improve attention, impulse control, and reduce binge eating.

name: Lisinopril
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) in adults and children 6 years and older, heart failure, and to improve survival after a heart attack. Also helps protect kidney function in certain patients with diabetes and kidney disease.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), reducing production of angiotensin II, which relaxes and widens blood vessels, lowers blood pressure, and reduces the heart’s workload.

name: Lithium
description: Used to treat bipolar disorder by stabilizing mood and preventing episodes of mania and depression. Also prescribed for mania, hypomania, certain types of depression, schizoaffective disorder, and sometimes for cluster headaches and other psychiatric conditions when other treatments are not effective.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits the enzyme glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3), modulates neurotransmitter signaling, and promotes neuroprotection and mood stabilization by affecting multiple pathways in the brain, including inositol metabolism and anti-apoptotic effects.

name: Lofexidine
description: Used to manage symptoms of opioid withdrawal, such as muscle aches, stomach cramps, anxiety, chills, and insomnia, when stopping opioid medications. It is typically prescribed for short-term use during detoxification and does not treat opioid addiction itself.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as an alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist, reducing the release of norepinephrine in the brain and nervous system, which helps lessen the intensity of withdrawal symptoms.

name: Loperamide
description: Used to control and relieve symptoms of acute and chronic diarrhea, including diarrhea caused by inflammatory bowel disease, and to reduce stool output in people with ileostomies.
mechanism_of_action: Acts on mu-opioid receptors in the gut to slow intestinal movement, increasing the time stool remains in the intestine, which allows more water to be absorbed and results in firmer stools and fewer bowel movements.

name: Lopressor
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), stable angina (chest pain), and to reduce the risk of death after a heart attack. Also helps decrease the workload on the heart and may be used in other heart-related conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Selectively blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, slowing heart rate, reducing heart contraction force, and lowering blood pressure by decreasing the effects of adrenaline and stress hormones on the heart.

name: Losartan
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), lower the risk of stroke in people with high blood pressure and left ventricular hypertrophy, and protect the kidneys in people with type 2 diabetes and kidney disease. It may also be used alone or with other medications for these purposes.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks angiotensin II type 1 receptors, preventing angiotensin II from tightening blood vessels and signaling the release of aldosterone. This relaxes blood vessels, lowers blood pressure, and reduces strain on the heart and kidneys.

name: Lovastatin
description: Used to lower high cholesterol and triglyceride levels in the blood, reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, and the need for heart surgery in people with or at risk for heart disease. Also prescribed to treat inherited forms of high cholesterol in adults and children ages 10 and older.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the HMG-CoA reductase enzyme in the liver, reducing cholesterol production and lowering LDL (“bad”) cholesterol, which helps prevent cholesterol buildup in arteries.

name: Lovenox
description: Used to prevent and treat blood clots, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), especially after certain surgeries or in patients with limited mobility. Also used to reduce the risk of complications from unstable angina and certain types of heart attacks (such as ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, STEMI).
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the activity of antithrombin III to inactivate clotting factor Xa (and to a lesser extent, factor IIa), preventing the formation and growth of blood clots.

name: Lyrica
description: Used to treat nerve pain from conditions like diabetic neuropathy, shingles (postherpetic neuralgia), and spinal cord injury; fibromyalgia; and as an add-on therapy for partial-onset seizures in epilepsy.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to the α2-δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels in the nervous system, reducing calcium influx and decreasing the release of excitatory neurotransmitters to calm overactive nerves and relieve pain or prevent seizures.

name: Macrobid
description: Used to treat acute uncomplicated urinary tract infections (UTIs), particularly cystitis, caused by susceptible bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Not indicated for kidney infections (pyelonephritis) or complicated urinary tract infections.
mechanism_of_action: Converted by bacterial enzymes into reactive intermediates that damage bacterial DNA, RNA, protein, and cell wall synthesis, inhibiting essential cellular processes and killing bacteria in the urine.

name: Magnesium
description: Used to treat and prevent low magnesium levels (hypomagnesemia), relieve constipation, act as an antacid for heartburn and indigestion, manage seizures in eclampsia and pre-eclampsia, and treat certain types of irregular heartbeat (arrhythmias). Also supports bone health, blood pressure regulation, blood sugar control, and may be used as part of bowel preparation for medical procedures.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a cofactor for over 300 enzymes, supporting energy production, nerve transmission, muscle contraction, and heart rhythm by regulating ion transport and stabilizing cell membranes.

name: Meclizine
description: Used to prevent and treat nausea, vomiting, and dizziness caused by motion sickness, as well as to manage vertigo associated with inner ear disorders such as Meniere’s disease.
