mechanism_of_action: Blocks histamine H1 receptors and has anticholinergic effects in the brain, reducing activity in the vomiting center and vestibular system to relieve motion sickness and vertigo symptoms.

name: Medrol
description: Used to treat a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, including arthritis, lupus, psoriasis, ulcerative colitis, severe allergies, certain blood, eye, skin, lung, and endocrine disorders, and as part of cancer therapy. Also prescribed for hormone disorders like adrenal insufficiency and to manage acute flare-ups of chronic diseases.
mechanism_of_action: Reduces inflammation and suppresses immune responses by binding to glucocorticoid receptors, altering gene expression, and decreasing the production of inflammatory chemicals in the body.

name: Meloxicam
description: Used to relieve pain and inflammation caused by osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis in adults and children.
mechanism_of_action: Preferentially blocks the cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzyme, reducing the production of prostaglandins that cause pain and inflammation, while having less effect on COX-1 at lower doses.

name: Meropenem
description: Used to treat serious bacterial infections, including complicated intra-abdominal infections, complicated skin and skin structure infections, bacterial meningitis (especially in children), hospital-acquired and community-acquired pneumonia, septicemia, febrile neutropenia, complicated urinary tract infections, and infections caused by multidrug-resistant bacteria. Often reserved for severe or hospital-acquired infections when other antibiotics may not be effective.
mechanism_of_action: Penetrates bacterial cells and binds to penicillin-binding proteins, inhibiting cell wall synthesis and leading to bacterial cell death. It is resistant to most beta-lactamases, making it effective against a broad range of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

name: Methadone
description: Used to treat opioid use disorder by reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings, and as a long-term maintenance therapy to help people stop or avoid illicit opioid use. Also prescribed for severe, chronic pain when other pain treatments are inadequate.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a full agonist at mu-opioid receptors to relieve withdrawal and block the effects of other opioids, and also blocks NMDA receptors, which helps reduce pain and opioid tolerance.

name: Methocarbamol
description: Used to relieve discomfort from acute, painful musculoskeletal conditions such as muscle spasms, strains, and sprains. Often used short-term as an adjunct to rest, physical therapy, and pain relievers.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a centrally acting muscle relaxant, likely by depressing nerve activity in the spinal cord and brain, which helps reduce muscle spasms without directly affecting muscle fibers.

name: Methotrexate
description: Used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, and other autoimmune or inflammatory conditions (such as lupus, vasculitis, and severe psoriasis). Also prescribed at higher doses for certain cancers, including leukemia, lymphoma, and some solid tumors. It helps reduce inflammation, control immune system overactivity, and slow disease progression in autoimmune diseases.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks enzymes involved in folate metabolism-primarily dihydrofolate reductase-to inhibit DNA synthesis in rapidly dividing cells (important for cancer treatment). In autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, it increases adenosine levels and modulates immune cell activity, leading to reduced inflammation and immune response.

name: Midazolam
description: Used to produce sedation, relieve anxiety, and cause drowsiness before and during surgical or diagnostic procedures; also used for anesthesia induction, procedural sedation, and the acute treatment of seizures, especially status epilepticus. Sometimes given for severe agitation or as a premedication before anesthesia in adults and children.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA at GABA-A receptors in the brain, increasing chloride channel opening and causing neuronal inhibition, which leads to sedation, anxiolysis, amnesia, muscle relaxation, and anticonvulsant effects.

name: Midodrine
description: Used to treat low blood pressure that causes symptoms, particularly orthostatic hypotension (a sudden drop in blood pressure when standing), to help prevent dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting that interferes with daily activities.
mechanism_of_action: Converted in the body to its active form, desglymidodrine, which selectively stimulates alpha-1 adrenergic receptors on blood vessels, causing them to constrict and thereby increasing blood pressure.

name: MiraLAX
description: Used to relieve occasional constipation by softening stool and making it easier to pass. It is available over-the-counter and typically produces a bowel movement within 1 to 3 days. Not intended for long-term use without medical supervision.
mechanism_of_action: Works as an osmotic laxative by drawing water into the colon, which softens stool and increases stool frequency without causing harsh side effects like cramping or urgency.

name: Mobic
description: Used to relieve pain, tenderness, swelling, and stiffness caused by osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and juvenile rheumatoid arthritis in adults and children 2 years and older.
mechanism_of_action: Preferentially blocks the COX-2 enzyme, reducing production of prostaglandins that cause pain and inflammation, while having less effect on COX-1 at lower doses.

name: Mounjaro
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes, in combination with diet and exercise. Also causes significant weight loss, though weight loss is considered an additional benefit rather than an official FDA-approved use for this brand.
mechanism_of_action: Activates both GLP-1 and GIP receptors, mimicking natural gut hormones to increase insulin release when blood sugar is high, reduce sugar production by the liver, slow digestion, and decrease appetite, resulting in improved blood sugar control and weight loss.

name: Naloxone
description: Used to rapidly reverse opioid overdose and its life-threatening effects, such as respiratory depression, unconsciousness, and pinpoint pupils. Also included in some combination medications to deter opioid abuse and as an adjunct in opioid dependence treatment. Sometimes used off-label for other indications like clonidine overdose and opioid-induced constipation.
mechanism_of_action: Competitively blocks opioid receptors, especially the mu-opioid receptor, displacing opioids and reversing their effects on breathing and consciousness.

name: Naltrexone
description: Used to treat opioid use disorder and alcohol use disorder by reducing cravings, blocking the euphoric and sedative effects of opioids and alcohol, and helping prevent relapse as part of a comprehensive treatment plan. Also available in combination with bupropion for weight management and sometimes used off-label for other conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks mu-opioid receptors in the brain, preventing opioids and alcohol from producing their usual rewarding effects, which reduces cravings and helps maintain abstinence.

name: Naprosyn
description: Used to relieve pain, inflammation, and swelling in conditions such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, gout, juvenile arthritis, tendonitis, bursitis, menstrual cramps, muscle aches, back pain, headaches, dental pain, and to reduce fever.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) enzymes, reducing the production of prostaglandins that cause pain, inflammation, and fever.

name: Nexplanon
description: Used to prevent pregnancy as a long-acting, reversible form of birth control. The small, flexible implant is inserted under the skin of the upper arm and provides contraception for up to 3 years (some sources note up to 5 years, but FDA labeling specifies 3 years).
mechanism_of_action: Continuously releases etonogestrel, a progestin hormone, which primarily prevents ovulation. It also thickens cervical mucus to block sperm and thins the uterine lining to reduce the likelihood of implantation.

name: Nicardipine
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and control angina (chest pain). It is also used in certain cases for the management of hypertensive emergencies, perioperative blood pressure control, and sometimes for cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks calcium entry into heart and vascular smooth muscle cells, causing blood vessels to relax and widen. This lowers blood pressure, reduces the heart’s workload, and increases blood and oxygen supply to the heart.

name: Nifedipine
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and to control chest pain (angina), including chronic stable angina and Prinzmetal’s (variant) angina. Also sometimes used for Raynaud’s phenomenon, certain types of premature labor, and other vascular conditions as determined by a healthcare provider.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks L-type calcium channels in the smooth muscle of blood vessels, relaxing and widening them. This lowers blood pressure and increases blood and oxygen supply to the heart, reducing its workload and relieving angina.

name: Nitroglycerin
description: Used to treat and prevent angina (chest pain) caused by coronary artery disease, and also for acute heart failure, severe hypertension, anal fissures, and to manage coronary artery spasms. It is often administered as sublingual tablets or sprays for rapid relief of chest pain, and also comes in patches, ointments, and injectable forms for other indications.
mechanism_of_action: Converted in the body to nitric oxide, which relaxes and widens blood vessels (vasodilation), primarily veins, reducing the heart’s workload and increasing blood and oxygen supply to the heart.

name: Norco
description: Used to relieve moderate to severe pain when pain is not controlled by non-opioid medications. Also sometimes used to suppress cough, but primarily prescribed for pain management when other treatments are inadequate.
mechanism_of_action: Hydrocodone binds to mu-opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord, blocking pain signals and altering the perception of pain. Acetaminophen enhances pain relief by inhibiting pain signal transmission, likely through blocking prostaglandin synthesis in the brain.

name: Norflex
description: Used to relieve pain and stiffness from acute, painful musculoskeletal conditions such as strains, sprains, muscle injuries, and muscle spasms. Typically prescribed short-term as an adjunct to rest and physical therapy.
mechanism_of_action: Acts in the central nervous system as a muscle relaxant with anticholinergic and mild analgesic properties, likely reducing muscle spasms and pain by blocking certain nerve signals and altering pain perception in the brain.

name: NovoLog
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults and children with diabetes mellitus, including both type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Often administered before meals as a rapid-acting insulin and sometimes used in insulin pumps for continuous delivery.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a rapid-acting insulin analog that binds to insulin receptors on muscle and fat cells, promoting cellular uptake of glucose and inhibiting glucose production by the liver. This quickly lowers blood sugar after injection due to its fast absorption and onset of action.

name: Nystatin
description: Used to treat and prevent fungal infections caused by Candida species, including oral thrush (mouth), esophageal candidiasis, intestinal candidiasis, skin infections (such as diaper rash), and vaginal yeast infections. It is also sometimes used to prevent fungal infections in people at high risk, such as those with weakened immune systems.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, forming pores that disrupt membrane integrity and cause leakage of cellular contents, leading to fungal cell death.

name: Ofloxacin
description: Used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including pneumonia, bronchitis, skin infections, urinary tract infections (UTIs), prostate infections, and certain sexually transmitted diseases such as gonorrhea and chlamydia. It is also used for infections of the bladder, reproductive organs, and sometimes for other infections like Legionnaires’ disease, bone and joint infections, and infectious diarrhea, depending on bacterial susceptibility.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, enzymes needed for DNA replication and repair, which stops bacterial growth and leads to cell death.

name: Olanzapine
description: Used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar I disorder, including manic or mixed episodes, as well as maintenance therapy. Also prescribed in combination with fluoxetine for depressive episodes of bipolar I disorder and for treatment-resistant depression. Sometimes used off-label for agitation, chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, and other psychiatric or mood disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks multiple neurotransmitter receptors in the brain, especially dopamine D2 and serotonin 5HT2A receptors, reducing abnormal brain activity to improve mood, thinking, and behavior.

name: Omeprazole
description: Used to treat and prevent conditions caused by excess stomach acid, including gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), heartburn, erosive esophagitis, stomach and duodenal ulcers, and conditions with excessive acid production such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Also used in combination therapy to eradicate Helicobacter pylori infections and reduce the risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding in critically ill patients.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the stomach’s proton pumps (H+/K+ ATPase enzymes) in parietal cells, which are responsible for the final step in gastric acid production, thereby significantly reducing stomach acid secretion.

name: Opdivo
description: Used to treat a variety of cancers, including melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), malignant pleural mesothelioma, renal cell carcinoma, classical Hodgkin lymphoma, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, urothelial carcinoma, colorectal cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma, esophageal cancer, gastric cancer, gastroesophageal junction cancer, and esophageal adenocarcinoma. It is often used in advanced, metastatic, or previously treated cancers and may be combined with other cancer therapies.
mechanism_of_action: A monoclonal antibody that binds to the PD-1 receptor on T cells, blocking cancer cells from turning off the immune response. This enhances the body’s immune system to recognize and destroy cancer cells by preventing PD-L1 and PD-L2 proteins on tumor cells from deactivating T cells.

name: Oxcarbazepine
description: Used to treat partial (focal) seizures in adults and children, either alone or in combination with other medications. It is sometimes used off-label for conditions like bipolar disorder, neuropathic pain, and trigeminal neuralgia, particularly when other treatments have not worked.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels in the brain, stabilizing overexcited nerve membranes and reducing abnormal electrical activity to help prevent seizures. Its main effect comes from its active metabolite, licarbazepine.

name: Oxycodone
description: Used to relieve moderate to severe pain that cannot be managed with non-opioid medications. Immediate-release forms are prescribed for acute pain, while extended-release forms are used for chronic, severe pain requiring continuous, around-the-clock opioid therapy. Oxycodone is also available in combination with acetaminophen or aspirin for pain management.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to mu-opioid receptors (and to a lesser extent kappa and delta receptors) in the brain and spinal cord, blocking pain signals and altering pain perception by inhibiting neurotransmitter release and reducing neuronal excitability.

name: Ozempic
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes, reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events (such as heart attack and stroke) in those with type 2 diabetes and established heart disease, and slow the progression of kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease. It is not used for type 1 diabetes or as a weight loss drug, though weight loss is a common benefit.
mechanism_of_action: Mimics the natural hormone GLP-1 by binding to GLP-1 receptors, which increases insulin release when blood sugar is high, decreases glucose production by the liver, slows stomach emptying, and reduces appetite, resulting in improved blood sugar control and potential weight loss.

name: Pantoprazole
description: Used to treat conditions caused by excess stomach acid, including gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with erosive esophagitis, maintenance of healing of erosive esophagitis, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, and stomach ulcers. It helps heal and prevent damage to the esophagus from acid reflux and is also used for pathological hypersecretory conditions in adults and children 5 years and older.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the stomach’s proton pumps (H+/K+ ATPase enzymes) in parietal cells, irreversibly inhibiting the final step of gastric acid production and significantly reducing stomach acid secretion.

name: Paroxetine
description: Used to treat depression, generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Also prescribed for hot flashes related to menopause and sometimes for other conditions such as chronic headaches or certain types of nerve pain.
mechanism_of_action: Selectively blocks the reuptake of serotonin in the brain, increasing serotonin levels and helping to improve mood, reduce anxiety, and relieve other symptoms of the treated conditions.

name: Paxlovid
description: Used to treat mild to moderate COVID-19 in adults (and some adolescents) who are at high risk for progressing to severe disease, hospitalization, or death. Treatment must begin within five days of symptom onset.
mechanism_of_action: Combines nirmatrelvir, which blocks a key viral enzyme needed for SARS-CoV-2 to replicate, with ritonavir, which slows the breakdown of nirmatrelvir in the body so it remains effective longer.

name: Phenergan
description: Used to treat allergy symptoms such as itching, runny nose, sneezing, watery eyes, hives, and skin rashes; also used to prevent and treat nausea and vomiting (including motion sickness), provide sedation before or after surgery, and relieve short-term insomnia or anxiety related to procedures.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks histamine H1 receptors to reduce allergic symptoms and also acts on muscarinic and dopamine receptors in the brain to prevent nausea, vomiting, and induce sedation.

name: Phenobarbital
description: Used to control and prevent various types of seizures (except absence seizures), manage status epilepticus, and provide sedation for anxiety, insomnia, and preoperative procedures. Also used in alcohol and benzodiazepine withdrawal, and sometimes for certain metabolic disorders or as a sedative in intensive care.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances GABA-A receptor activity to increase chloride ion flow into neurons, causing hyperpolarization and decreased neuronal excitability; also inhibits excitatory neurotransmission by blocking glutamate receptors.

name: Plaquenil
description: Used to treat and prevent malaria, as well as to manage autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), discoid lupus, and sometimes Sjögren’s syndrome. It helps reduce inflammation, pain, and swelling in these conditions and is a standard therapy for lupus.
mechanism_of_action: Suppresses activation of Toll-like receptors in immune cells, reducing the production of inflammatory signals and modulating the immune response; also interferes with parasite growth in red blood cells when used for malaria.

name: Pravastatin
description: Used to lower high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, and other cardiovascular events in people with or at risk for heart disease, and slow the progression of atherosclerosis. Also prescribed for familial hypercholesterolemia and as adjunct therapy with diet and exercise.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks HMG-CoA reductase, the key enzyme in cholesterol production, leading to decreased cholesterol synthesis, increased LDL clearance from the blood, lower LDL and triglycerides, and higher HDL cholesterol.

name: Prazosin
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and to manage nightmares and sleep disturbances associated with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Also prescribed for congestive heart failure, Raynaud’s disease, and pheochromocytoma.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks alpha-1 adrenergic receptors on blood vessels, causing them to relax and widen, which lowers blood pressure and improves blood flow.

name: Prednisolone
description: Used to treat a wide range of conditions including allergies, asthma, inflammatory and autoimmune diseases (such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus), skin disorders, blood disorders, certain cancers, inflammatory bowel disease, and to prevent organ rejection after transplant. It works by reducing inflammation and calming overactive immune responses.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to glucocorticoid receptors to suppress immune system activity and decrease inflammation by altering gene expression and reducing the production of inflammatory chemicals.

name: Prednisone
description: Used to treat a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions such as asthma, allergic reactions, arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, lupus, multiple sclerosis, certain cancers, and to prevent organ rejection after transplant. Also used to replace low levels of corticosteroids in adrenal insufficiency.
mechanism_of_action: Converted in the liver to prednisolone, which binds to glucocorticoid receptors, suppresses immune system activity, and reduces inflammation by altering gene expression and decreasing the production of inflammatory chemicals.

name: Propranolol
description: Used to treat high blood pressure, angina (chest pain), irregular heart rhythms (such as atrial fibrillation), prevention of migraine headaches, essential tremor, hypertrophic subaortic stenosis, symptoms of anxiety (including performance anxiety), and to reduce risk after a heart attack. Also used for certain types of infantile hemangioma and as adjunct therapy in conditions like thyrotoxicosis and pheochromocytoma.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors throughout the body, reducing heart rate, blood pressure, and the heart’s workload by inhibiting the effects of adrenaline and noradrenaline on the heart and blood vessels.

name: Provigil
description: Used to improve wakefulness in people with excessive daytime sleepiness caused by narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), or shift work sleep disorder. It does not treat the underlying cause of these conditions but helps reduce symptoms of sleepiness.
mechanism_of_action: Promotes wakefulness by affecting brain chemicals involved in sleep-wake regulation; the exact mechanism is unclear but is thought to increase dopamine and mimic certain stimulant effects without the same structure as amphetamines.

name: Reglan
description: Used to treat heartburn caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in people who have not responded to other treatments, and to relieve symptoms of diabetic gastroparesis (slow stomach emptying), such as nausea, vomiting, and feeling full after meals. Also used short-term to prevent nausea and vomiting from chemotherapy, surgery, or certain medical procedures.
mechanism_of_action: Increases muscle contractions in the upper digestive tract to speed stomach emptying and intestinal transit; also blocks dopamine receptors in the brain to help prevent nausea and vomiting.

name: Remeron
description: Used to treat major depressive disorder (MDD) in adults. Also prescribed off-label for insomnia, to stimulate appetite, and to manage certain anxiety disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks central presynaptic α2-adrenergic receptors to increase norepinephrine and serotonin release, and antagonizes certain serotonin (5-HT2, 5-HT3) and histamine (H1) receptors, resulting in antidepressant, anxiolytic, and sedating effects.

name: Remicade
description: Used to treat autoimmune and inflammatory conditions such as Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and plaque psoriasis. It helps reduce symptoms, induce and maintain remission, and improve quality of life for people with these chronic diseases.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to and neutralizes tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), a key inflammatory protein, thereby blocking the inflammatory cascade that drives autoimmune disease symptoms and tissue damage.

name: Restoril
description: Used to treat short-term insomnia by helping people fall asleep faster, stay asleep longer, and reduce nighttime awakenings. It is typically prescribed for up to 7–10 days and may also be used off-label for anxiety or related sleep disturbances.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA in the brain, slowing down nervous system activity to induce drowsiness and promote sleep.

name: Risperdal
description: Used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder (including manic and mixed episodes), and irritability or behavioral problems associated with autism in children and adolescents. Also sometimes prescribed off-label for severe behavioral disturbances, aggression, and as an adjunct in treatment-resistant depression or obsessive-compulsive disorder.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2 receptors in the brain, balancing neurotransmitter activity to reduce psychotic symptoms, stabilize mood, and decrease aggression or irritability.

name: Ritalin
description: Used to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), attention deficit disorder (ADD), and narcolepsy by improving attention, focus, and impulse control. Sometimes used off-label for certain cases of depression, fatigue, or cognitive symptoms in other conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain, increasing their levels in the synaptic cleft, which enhances attention, alertness, and impulse control.

name: Robaxin
description: Used to relieve discomfort from acute, painful musculoskeletal conditions such as muscle spasms, strains, or injuries, typically as an adjunct to rest and physical therapy. The injectable form is also used to manage muscle spasms caused by tetanus.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a centrally acting muscle relaxant, likely by depressing nerve activity in the spinal cord and brain, which reduces muscle spasms and pain without directly affecting muscle fibers.

name: Rosuvastatin
description: Used to lower high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, slow the buildup of fatty deposits in blood vessels, and reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, and other cardiovascular events. Also prescribed for familial hypercholesterolemia and to prevent cardiovascular disease in people at risk.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks HMG-CoA reductase, the key liver enzyme needed to make cholesterol, which lowers LDL (“bad”) cholesterol, raises HDL (“good”) cholesterol, and reduces triglycerides in the blood.

name: Sabril
description: Used to treat infantile spasms in children 1 month to 2 years old, and as add-on therapy for difficult-to-treat complex partial (focal) seizures in adults and children 2 years and older who have not responded adequately to several other seizure medications. It is typically reserved for cases where other treatments have failed due to the risk of serious side effects, including permanent vision loss.
mechanism_of_action: Irreversibly blocks the enzyme GABA transaminase, leading to increased levels of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA in the brain, which helps stabilize electrical activity and control seizures.

name: Senna
description: Used for short-term relief of constipation and to empty the bowels before surgery or medical procedures such as colonoscopy. It is FDA-approved as an over-the-counter (OTC) stimulant laxative for adults and children ages 2 years and older. Other uses, such as for irritable bowel syndrome, hemorrhoids, or weight loss, are not well supported by evidence and are not FDA-approved.
mechanism_of_action: Stimulates the lining of the bowel to increase intestinal movement and fluid secretion, causing a laxative effect that results in a bowel movement, typically within 6–12 hours after oral use.

name: Seroquel
description: Used to treat schizophrenia in adults and adolescents, bipolar disorder (including manic and depressive episodes), and as an add-on treatment for major depressive disorder in adults. Also prescribed off-label for anxiety, insomnia, and other mood disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks serotonin (5-HT2) and dopamine (D2) receptors in the brain, balancing neurotransmitter activity to reduce psychotic symptoms and stabilize mood; also affects histamine and adrenergic receptors, contributing to sedative and blood pressure-lowering effects.

name: Sertraline
description: Used to treat major depressive disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), panic disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), social anxiety disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Also prescribed off-label for generalized anxiety disorder, premature ejaculation, and other conditions as determined by a healthcare provider.
mechanism_of_action: Increases serotonin levels in the brain by selectively blocking its reuptake into nerve cells, which helps improve mood, reduce anxiety, and relieve symptoms of depression and related disorders.

name: Simvastatin
description: Used to lower high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, and other cardiovascular events, and slow the progression of atherosclerosis in adults and children as young as 10 with certain inherited cholesterol disorders. Also prescribed to decrease the risk of heart problems in people with risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks HMG-CoA reductase, the key liver enzyme needed to make cholesterol, which lowers LDL (“bad”) cholesterol, raises HDL (“good”) cholesterol, and reduces triglycerides in the blood.

name: Sinemet
description: Used to treat symptoms of Parkinson’s disease, such as muscle stiffness, tremors, spasms, and poor muscle control, as well as parkinsonism caused by encephalitis, carbon monoxide poisoning, or manganese toxicity.
mechanism_of_action: Combines levodopa, which is converted to dopamine in the brain to relieve symptoms, with carbidopa, which prevents levodopa’s breakdown outside the brain, allowing more levodopa to reach the brain and increasing its effectiveness.

name: Singulair
description: Used to prevent and manage asthma symptoms, relieve seasonal and year-round allergy symptoms (allergic rhinitis), and prevent exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. It is prescribed for adults and children as young as 12 months for asthma, and for allergies in children as young as 6 months. Not for acute asthma attacks.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks leukotriene receptors in the airways, preventing the action of leukotrienes-chemicals that cause airway inflammation, swelling, and tightening-thereby reducing asthma and allergy symptoms.

name: Soliris
description: Used to treat rare autoimmune and blood disorders, including paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS), generalized myasthenia gravis (gMG) in anti-acetylcholine receptor antibody-positive adults, and neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) in adults. Also approved for aHUS in children ages 2 months and older.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to complement protein C5 in the blood, blocking its activation and preventing the formation of the terminal complement complex. This reduces abnormal immune attacks on blood cells, blood vessels, nerves, and muscles in the targeted conditions.

name: SoluMEDROL
description: Used to treat a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, including arthritis, lupus, severe allergies, asthma, ulcerative colitis, psoriasis, adrenal insufficiency, blood and bone marrow disorders, skin and eye diseases, and flare-ups of multiple sclerosis. It is also used for severe allergic reactions, respiratory distress, and other conditions where rapid suppression of inflammation or immune response is needed.
mechanism_of_action: Suppresses the immune system and reduces inflammation by blocking the release of substances that cause swelling, redness, and allergic reactions.

name: somatropin
description: Used to treat growth hormone deficiency in children and adults, promote growth in children with certain growth disorders (such as Turner syndrome, Prader-Willi syndrome, chronic kidney disease, Noonan syndrome, SHOX deficiency, and children born small for gestational age), manage short bowel syndrome in adults, and increase body weight and physical endurance in patients with HIV-associated wasting syndrome.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a synthetic human growth hormone that binds to growth hormone receptors, directly stimulating growth and metabolism, and indirectly increasing insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) production, which promotes bone and tissue growth and regulates metabolism.

name: Sotalol
description: Used to treat and prevent certain serious, potentially life-threatening abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias), including ventricular tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and atrial flutter. It helps maintain normal heart rhythm in people with a history of these conditions and is sometimes used off-label for other arrhythmias.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks beta-adrenergic receptors and potassium channels in the heart, slowing the heart rate and prolonging the heart’s electrical recovery period to prevent and correct abnormal heart rhythms.

name: Spironolactone
description: Used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, fluid retention (edema) due to heart, liver, or kidney disease, and primary hyperaldosteronism. Also used to prevent low potassium levels (hypokalemia) and sometimes prescribed off-label for conditions like acne, hirsutism, and certain hormone-related disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks aldosterone receptors in the kidneys, causing the body to excrete sodium and water while retaining potassium; also has antiandrogen effects by blocking androgen receptors.

name: Suboxone
description: Used to treat opioid use disorder (OUD) by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms, supporting recovery, and lowering the risk of relapse. It is prescribed as part of a medication-assisted treatment (MAT) program, often alongside counseling and behavioral therapy, and is not intended for use as a pain medication.
mechanism_of_action: Combines buprenorphine, a partial opioid agonist that partially activates opioid receptors to relieve withdrawal and cravings without producing full opioid effects, and naloxone, an opioid antagonist that discourages misuse by blocking opioid effects if injected; together, they stabilize opioid receptors and help prevent relapse.

name: Sudafed
description: Used to relieve nasal and sinus congestion and pressure caused by the common cold, sinusitis, hay fever, and upper respiratory allergies. Also helps clear congestion of the eustachian tubes that drain fluid from the inner ears.
mechanism_of_action: Shrinks blood vessels in the nasal passages by stimulating alpha-adrenergic receptors, leading to reduced swelling and congestion; also promotes release of norepinephrine, further activating adrenergic receptors to open nasal airways.

name: Sulfasalazine
description: Used to treat and prevent mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, manage rheumatoid arthritis (especially in patients who have not responded to or cannot tolerate other treatments), and polyarticular-course juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. It is also sometimes used for Crohn’s disease, psoriatic arthritis, and other inflammatory bowel diseases or arthritis-related conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Broken down by colon bacteria into sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA); 5-ASA reduces inflammation in the colon by blocking inflammatory chemicals like prostaglandins and leukotrienes, while sulfapyridine has immune-modulating effects. Together, they lower inflammation and help control symptoms.

name: Sumatriptan
description: Used to treat acute migraine attacks with or without aura and to relieve symptoms of cluster headaches. It is taken at the onset of headache to reduce pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light or sound, but does not prevent future attacks or reduce their frequency.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a selective serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonist, narrowing blood vessels in the brain and blocking pain signals and the release of inflammatory substances, thereby relieving headache symptoms.

name: Symbicort
description: Used as a long-term maintenance treatment to control and prevent symptoms of asthma in adults and children ages 6 and older, especially when asthma is not well-controlled on other medications. Also prescribed to improve symptoms and reduce exacerbations in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. Not intended for relief of acute asthma or COPD attacks.
mechanism_of_action: Combines budesonide, a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation in the airways, with formoterol, a long-acting beta2-agonist that relaxes airway muscles to improve breathing and keep airways open.

name: Synthroid
description: Used to treat hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid), certain types of goiter (enlarged thyroid gland), and to suppress thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) as part of the management of some thyroid cancers. It replaces or supplements the body’s natural thyroid hormone to restore normal metabolic activity and is approved for use in both adults and children.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a synthetic form of thyroxine (T4), the main hormone produced by the thyroid gland. It is converted in the body to the active hormone triiodothyronine (T3), which binds to nuclear thyroid receptors and regulates gene expression to maintain normal metabolism, growth, and development.

name: Tacrolimus
description: Used to prevent organ rejection after solid organ transplants (such as kidney, liver, heart, and lung) by suppressing the immune system. Also used topically to treat moderate to severe atopic dermatitis (eczema) in patients who have not responded to other treatments, and sometimes for other autoimmune or inflammatory conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks calcineurin by binding to FKBP-12 in immune cells, which inhibits T-cell activation and the production of inflammatory cytokines (such as IL-2), thereby reducing immune responses that can lead to organ rejection or skin inflammation.

name: Tadalafil
description: Used to treat erectile dysfunction (trouble getting or keeping an erection), symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) such as difficulty urinating, and pulmonary arterial hypertension (high blood pressure in the lungs). Also sometimes used off-label for Raynaud’s phenomenon and prevention of high-altitude pulmonary edema.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the enzyme phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5), leading to relaxation of smooth muscle and increased blood flow in specific tissues. For erectile dysfunction, it increases blood flow to the penis during sexual stimulation; for BPH, it relaxes muscles in the bladder and prostate; for pulmonary arterial hypertension, it relaxes blood vessels in the lungs to lower blood pressure.

name: Tamiflu
description: Used to treat and prevent influenza (flu) types A and B in people 2 weeks of age and older for treatment, and in people 1 year and older for prevention. It is most effective when started within 48 hours of the onset of flu symptoms and can help reduce the duration and severity of symptoms. Also used to help prevent the flu after exposure to someone with the virus, but it does not replace the annual flu vaccine and does not treat the common cold.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the neuraminidase enzyme on the surface of influenza viruses, preventing the virus from releasing new copies of itself from infected cells, thereby limiting the spread of infection within the body.

name: Terazosin
description: Used to treat symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH, enlarged prostate) such as difficulty urinating, and to lower high blood pressure (hypertension), though it is not a first-choice option for blood pressure. It may also be used off-label for conditions like chronic prostatitis, pelvic pain syndrome, and certain urinary symptoms related to other causes.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks alpha-1 adrenergic receptors in smooth muscle of blood vessels, prostate, and bladder neck, causing these muscles to relax. This lowers blood pressure by widening blood vessels and improves urine flow by reducing prostate and bladder neck resistance.

name: Tetracycline
description: Used to treat a wide variety of bacterial infections, including acne, respiratory tract infections (such as bronchitis and pneumonia), tick-borne diseases (like Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Lyme disease), sexually transmitted infections (such as chlamydia), eye infections (trachoma, inclusion conjunctivitis), urinary tract infections, plague, cholera, anthrax, and certain infections when penicillin cannot be used. It is also effective against some parasitic infections and is sometimes used for malaria and as part of therapy for Helicobacter pylori ulcers.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks bacterial protein synthesis by reversibly binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, preventing the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the mRNA-ribosome complex, which stops bacteria from making proteins needed for growth and replication.

name: Topamax
description: Used to treat and prevent seizures in adults and children with epilepsy, and to prevent migraine headaches in people 12 years and older. Also prescribed off-label for conditions such as bipolar disorder, weight loss, binge eating disorder, nerve pain, and certain psychiatric or headache disorders.
mechanism_of_action: Calms overactive nerve cells by blocking sodium channels, enhancing the activity of GABA (an inhibitory neurotransmitter), blocking glutamate (an excitatory neurotransmitter), and reducing excessive electrical activity in the brain, which helps prevent seizures and migraine episodes.

name: Toradol
description: Used for short-term (up to 5 days) management of moderate to severe acute pain, often after surgery or other medical procedures, when pain relief at the opioid level is needed but without the risk of dependence. Not indicated for minor or chronic pain, and not recommended for use in children or for more than 5 days due to risk of serious side effects.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks both cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzymes, reducing the production of prostaglandins-chemicals that cause pain, inflammation, and fever-thereby providing potent pain relief and anti-inflammatory effects.

name: Trazodone
description: Used primarily to treat major depressive disorder. It is also prescribed off-label for anxiety disorders, insomnia, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), and to augment other antidepressants, especially when insomnia or agitation is present. It may help improve mood, appetite, energy, and decrease anxiety and insomnia related to depression.
mechanism_of_action: Inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and blocks certain serotonin (5-HT2A, 5-HT2C), histamine (H1), and alpha-1 adrenergic receptors in the brain, which helps restore neurotransmitter balance to relieve depression, anxiety, and insomnia.

name: Trelegy Ellipta
description: Used as a once-daily maintenance inhaler to treat and control symptoms of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)-including chronic bronchitis and emphysema-and asthma in adults. It helps improve lung function, reduce symptoms such as wheezing and shortness of breath, and decrease the frequency of disease flare-ups. Trelegy Ellipta is not a rescue inhaler and should not be used for sudden breathing problems.
mechanism_of_action: Combines three medications: fluticasone furoate (an inhaled corticosteroid that reduces airway inflammation), umeclidinium (a long-acting muscarinic antagonist that relaxes airway muscles by blocking acetylcholine), and vilanterol (a long-acting beta2-adrenergic agonist that relaxes airway muscles by stimulating beta2 receptors). Together, they decrease inflammation and keep airways open for easier breathing.

name: Trileptal
description: Used to treat partial-onset (focal) seizures in adults and children, either alone or in combination with other medications. It is prescribed for epilepsy to help control abnormal electrical activity in the brain but does not cure the underlying condition.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks voltage-sensitive sodium channels in nerve cells, stabilizing overactive brain cells and reducing the spread of abnormal electrical activity that leads to seizures. Its main antiseizure effects come from its active metabolite, which further helps prevent repetitive neuronal firing.

name: Trulicity
description: Used to improve blood sugar control in adults and children 10 years and older with type 2 diabetes, alongside diet and exercise. Also prescribed to reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events (such as heart attack and stroke) in adults with type 2 diabetes who have established heart disease or multiple cardiovascular risk factors.
mechanism_of_action: Mimics the natural hormone GLP-1 by binding to GLP-1 receptors, which stimulates insulin release when blood sugar is high, lowers glucagon secretion from the liver, and slows stomach emptying, resulting in better blood sugar control.

name: Unasyn
description: Used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including skin and soft tissue infections, intra-abdominal infections, and gynecological infections caused by susceptible bacteria, especially when resistance to standard penicillins is suspected or confirmed.
mechanism_of_action: Combines a penicillin antibiotic that kills bacteria by disrupting cell wall synthesis with a beta-lactamase inhibitor that protects the antibiotic from bacterial enzymes, broadening its effectiveness against resistant bacteria.

name: Valacyclovir
description: Used to treat and prevent outbreaks of infections caused by herpes viruses, including genital herpes, cold sores (oral herpes), shingles (herpes zoster), and chickenpox in children. Also helps reduce the spread and recurrence of genital herpes.
mechanism_of_action: Converted in the body to acyclovir, which blocks viral DNA polymerase, stopping the herpes virus from replicating its genetic material and spreading in the body.

name: Valium
description: Used to treat anxiety disorders, muscle spasms, alcohol withdrawal symptoms, certain types of seizures, and sometimes for sedation before medical procedures. It is also used as an adjunct in the management of acute agitation and for short-term relief of insomnia or panic attacks.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA at GABA-A receptors in the brain, leading to calming, muscle-relaxing, anticonvulsant, and sedative effects.

name: Valproic acid
description: Used to treat various types of seizures in epilepsy, manage manic episodes in bipolar disorder, and prevent migraine headaches. It may also be used off-label for aggression and other psychiatric or neurological conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Increases levels of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA and blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilizing brain activity to reduce seizures and mood swings.

name: Valsartan
description: Used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension), heart failure, and to improve survival and reduce the risk of hospitalization after a heart attack. Also helps lower the risk of stroke and other cardiovascular events in at-risk patients.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks angiotensin II type 1 (AT1) receptors, preventing angiotensin II from tightening blood vessels and causing the body to retain sodium, resulting in relaxed blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and reduced strain on the heart.

name: Valtoco
description: Used for the acute treatment of seizure clusters (also known as acute repetitive seizures) in adults and children 2 years and older, providing rapid relief from episodes that differ from a person’s usual seizure pattern.
mechanism_of_action: Enhances the effects of GABA, a calming neurotransmitter, by binding to GABA-A receptors in the brain, which increases inhibitory signals and helps stop abnormal electrical activity during seizures.

name: Vancomycin
description: Used to treat serious infections caused by susceptible Gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), severe skin, bone, blood, heart (endocarditis), lung, and intestinal infections (such as Clostridioides difficile colitis), especially when other antibiotics are ineffective or not tolerated.
mechanism_of_action: Binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of bacterial cell wall precursors, blocking cell wall synthesis and cross-linking, which weakens and destroys susceptible Gram-positive bacteria.

name: Vibramycin
description: Used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, acne, skin and soft tissue infections, sexually transmitted infections (such as chlamydia and gonorrhea), certain eye infections, tick-borne illnesses (like Lyme disease and Rocky Mountain spotted fever), and to prevent malaria. Also used for inflammatory skin conditions like rosacea and as an alternative when penicillin cannot be used.
mechanism_of_action: Stops bacterial growth by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, blocking protein synthesis needed for bacteria to multiply.

name: Vimpat
description: Used to treat partial-onset (focal) seizures in adults and children 1 month and older, either alone or with other medications, and as adjunctive therapy for primary generalized tonic-clonic seizures in patients 4 years and older.
mechanism_of_action: Stabilizes overactive brain cells by selectively enhancing slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing abnormal electrical activity that leads to seizures.

name: Vistaril
description: Used to treat anxiety and tension, relieve itching from allergic conditions, help induce sleep before surgery, and manage symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and agitation. Also used as a sedative and for short-term management of insomnia or as an adjunct in certain medical procedures.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks histamine H1 receptors in the brain, producing antihistamine and sedative effects; also antagonizes serotonin and other receptors, which contributes to its calming and anti-anxiety properties.

name: Voltaren
description: Used to relieve pain, swelling, and inflammation associated with osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and acute muscle or joint injuries such as sprains and strains. Commonly applied as a topical gel for joint pain in the hands and knees, but also available as oral tablets, suppositories, and eye drops for other pain and inflammatory conditions.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2) enzymes, reducing the production of prostaglandins-chemicals that cause pain, inflammation, and swelling.

name: Vyvanse
description: Used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in adults and children ages 6 and older, and moderate to severe binge eating disorder in adults. Not indicated for weight loss or obesity.
mechanism_of_action: Acts as a prodrug that is converted in the body to dextroamphetamine, which increases levels of norepinephrine and dopamine in the brain by blocking their reuptake and promoting their release, leading to improved focus, impulse control, and reduced binge eating behavior.

name: Xarelto
description: Used to treat and prevent blood clots in the legs (deep vein thrombosis, DVT) and lungs (pulmonary embolism, PE), reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism in people with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, prevent blood clots after knee or hip replacement surgery, and lower the risk of heart attack, stroke, and other complications in people with coronary or peripheral artery disease. Also used in certain children for treatment and prevention of blood clots after initial anticoagulation therapy.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks factor Xa, an essential protein in the blood clotting process, which prevents the formation of blood clots.

name: Xcopri
description: Used to treat partial-onset (focal) seizures in adults, either alone or with other medications, helping to reduce the frequency of seizures in people with epilepsy.
mechanism_of_action: Reduces repetitive firing of brain cells by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels and positively modulating GABA-A ion channels, though the precise way it works to control seizures is not fully understood.

name: Zepbound
description: Used for long-term weight management in adults with obesity or overweight (with at least one weight-related health condition), and for treating moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adults with obesity. It is prescribed alongside a reduced-calorie diet and increased physical activity.
mechanism_of_action: Activates both GIP and GLP-1 receptors, which reduces appetite, slows digestion, and helps you feel full longer-leading to reduced calorie intake and weight loss.

name: Zetia
description: Used to lower high cholesterol, especially LDL (“bad”) cholesterol, in adults and children. Also prescribed for certain genetic cholesterol disorders (such as familial hypercholesterolemia and sitosterolemia), often as an add-on to statins or other cholesterol-lowering medications when diet and exercise alone are insufficient.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine by inhibiting the NPC1L1 protein, reducing the amount of cholesterol delivered to the liver and lowering blood cholesterol levels.

name: Zofran
description: Used to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery. Also prescribed for other causes of severe nausea and vomiting as determined by a healthcare provider.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks 5-HT3 (serotonin) receptors in the gut and brain, preventing signals that trigger nausea and vomiting.

name: Zoloft
description: Used to treat major depressive disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), panic disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), social anxiety disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Also prescribed for generalized anxiety disorder and other mental health conditions as determined by a healthcare provider.
mechanism_of_action: Increases serotonin levels in the brain by selectively blocking its reuptake into nerve cells, helping to improve mood, reduce anxiety, and relieve symptoms of depression and related disorders.

name: Zosyn
description: Used to treat a wide range of serious bacterial infections, including intra-abdominal infections (such as complicated appendicitis and peritonitis), hospital-acquired pneumonia, skin and soft tissue infections (including diabetic foot infections), female pelvic infections, and community-acquired pneumonia in adults and children 2 months and older.
mechanism_of_action: Combines a penicillin antibiotic that kills bacteria by blocking cell wall synthesis with a beta-lactamase inhibitor that protects the antibiotic from bacterial enzymes, allowing it to work against a broader range of bacteria, including those resistant to standard penicillins.

name: Zyprexa
description: Used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar I disorder in adults and adolescents, including manic or mixed episodes, and as part of combination therapy for depressive episodes in bipolar disorder. Also prescribed with fluoxetine for treatment-resistant depression. Available as oral tablets, orally disintegrating tablets, and intramuscular injections for acute agitation.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks dopamine and serotonin (5HT2) receptors in the brain, balancing neurotransmitter activity to reduce psychotic symptoms and stabilize mood.

name: Zyrtec
description: Used to relieve symptoms of seasonal and perennial allergies (hay fever and other upper respiratory allergies), such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and itching of the nose or throat. Also used to treat itching and swelling from chronic urticaria (hives) in adults and children.
mechanism_of_action: Blocks peripheral histamine H1 receptors, preventing histamine from causing allergy symptoms like sneezing, itching, and runny nose, with minimal sedation because it does not significantly cross into the brain.
